title.narrative: Health Corporate Indicators
Number of outpatient consultations

description.narrative: Number of outpatient consultations conducted by a healthcare practioner at a health facility supported by a Cordaid Health Programme

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Cash for people displaced by Kunduz fighting

description.narrative: Following a relatively quiet period, fighting between Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) and a non-state armed group (NSAG) flared up across the north-east of Afghanistan mainly in Badakhshan, Kunduz and Takhar provinces, resulting in some 9,150 families (approximately 64,050 people) being displaced by ongoing fighting since 16 August in Kunduz province and further displacement is expected. Some 6,670 HH are seeking refuge in Kunduz city, 2,500 HH fled to remote villages in Khanabad District, 1,500 HH in Imam Sahib and 580 HH in Aqtash district (Flash update 2 UNOCHA, 27 August, 2020). Many of the displaced families are staying with relatives or friends, or in rental accomodation while others are living in makeshift substandard shelters or in open spaces. The most urgent needs are shelter, food, Health care and safe drinking water. Due to lack of shelter, food and NFIs these vulnerable groups are experiencing the heat but soon the cold weather will arrive, and are also more prone to GBV and sexual violence. Furthermore, the lack of safe water and sanitation facilities are major public health and protection risks. The temporary shelters are overcrowded, making it impossible for people to follow the COVID-19 advise, further increasing risks on infections. Displacement is affecting women, girls, elderly, ill and disabled disproportionately, increasing their protection risks. Humanitarian partners are supporting local authorities to respond to people in need and have deployed inter-agency assessment teams to affected areas. During the regional cluster meeting on 26 August, both WFP and ECHO (through ERM) agreed to support 1,250 families with cash and food. However, with an estimated 50% (Kunduz Head of DoRR) of the affected people is vulnerable and in need of assistance, the assistance provided is not sufficient. As of yet the current response and attention for this crisis is insufficient. The regional UNOCHA office requested the Kabul UNOCHA office for uregent assistance of additional 2000 HH. There are very clear gaps identified in the response and needs are increasing rapidly especially as fighting continues. The aim of the assistance is therefore to address recently displaced people's most urgent, basic needs, saving lives, preventing the already precarious situation from worsening and families to apply negative coping strategies as many have already depleted their reserves.

Target vulnerable groups from the internally displaced people due to recent conflict in three districts of Kunduz (Kunduz City, Imam Sahib and Khan Abad). Basically those displaced or affected by the fighting and are sheltered in makeshift shelters, in the open and host households of the displaced persons. These vulnerable groups include; women, children, the elderly and chronicaly ill, persons with special needs, and people who's properties have been destroyed by the fighting and are now living in open spaces. for identification of most vulnerable HH, the displacement status with poor food consuption score and high coping startegies will be considered. for the inditification of beneficiraies the HEAT (ICCT endorsed tool) uploaded to the Kobo-Toolbox will be used which also give the realtime information on vulnerability.
To address the pressing needs of the displaced population with one month cash for their expenditure and providing COVID-19 awareness

title.narrative: Cash for Food for insecure people in Kot and Bati Kot districts of Nangarhar

description.narrative: Cordaid Conducted a raid need assessment during August 2020 in Kot, Bati Kot, Achin and Nazyan districts of Nangarhar. The assessment found that 76% of the respondents holds a National ID and that nearly 70% are under 18 yrs. 54.2% are females and 45.8% males. Half of the responding HH have been displaced or returning IDPs, making them more vulnerable to food insecurity and COVID-19. Because of high coping strategies practised by 82% of the respondents, combined with the vast majority of them (83%) having a poor food consumption score and no available food stocks (99%), people in the assessed areas are severely and acute food insecure. This is compounded by the lack of employment with more than 2/3 of the people being unemployed. Daily unskilled labour opportunities are limited (17%), which may be caused COVID-19 and related measures such as border closure. The effect of the COVID-19 measures is also reflected in people’s income. People saw their income more than halved over the past period, reducing their purchasing power dramatically whilst prices increased. Access to water and sanitation is limited to half of the people, implying that hygiene practices are low. This represents a major public health risk and the situation is now exacerbated by COVID-19. With poor hygiene practices and insufficient access to water for sanitation, people will not be able to take COVID-19 precautionary measures. Although the majority of the people is living in houses, more than half of them live in partially destroyed shelters and nearly half of them are living in overcrowded one-room shelter unable to social-distance. The lack of adequate shelter, water and sanitation facilities and privacy is affecting women and girls in particular, representing a protection risk for women and girls. Furthermore, women and girls are also disproportionately affected by COVID-19, bearing the brunt of the pandemic now as well in addition to displacement and conflict. With winter arriving soon, the assessed people also raised the need for heating materials, warm clothes and blankets. People lack the means to protect themselves against winter and are likely to resort to the use of negative coping strategies which include reduction in number of meals (27%), incurring debts (13%) and 96% will send the children out to collect fire wood, potentially causing protection risks for them. Markets assessments were also conducted and showed that in all 4 target districts, markets were functional and sufficiently stocked with food and NFIs supplies. Marko and Jalalabad were the main markets supplying materials to the districts market. Although markets at district level are small, they have the capacity to restock within 24 hours. At the time of assessment, markets were not facing any shortages of commodities.
The food insecure people in IPC 3 and 4

The overall objective of the project is to increase access to food of COVID-19 affected people who are in IPC phase 3 or phase 4 in Kot and Batikot of Nangarhar, through unconditional cash assistance, contributing to a minimum household food consumption score above 42.5. This will be achieved through cash for food assistance of half food basket for a period of 2 months, to complement beneficiaries' existing food stocks.

Bring Back Beirut Consortium - joint emergency response Beirut Blast

description.narrative: Estimated total number of direct beneficiaries targeted by the action is: 8,225 beneficiaries. For the selection of beneficiaries for cash for shelter, Caritas will follow the preliminary vulnerability criteria of the draft interagency shelter sector strategy

On 4 August 2020, at 18:00 (Beirut time), a warehouse at the Beirut Port containing 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate exploded. After an initial smaller explosion, a subsequent blast caused widespread destruction, with reports of damage up to 24 km from the port area. First responders searched through the night to reach survivors. Debris from the explosions obstructed efforts to assist victims. More than 160 deaths were reported, with an additional 5,000 persons injured, and more than 60 persons still missing. Hospitals have been overwhelmed with casualties as many ICUs were already reaching capacity with COVID-19 patients. The explosion also damaged countless buildings in Beirut.
Cordaid has agreed to pledge funds to support the joint emergency response implemented by the 3BC Consortium. The pledged funds will contribute to the project's overall objectives.

The project’s main objective is to contribute to the protection of vulnerable Lebanese, refugee, and migrant households against the negative impacts of the Beirut blast and COVID-19 pandemic while strengthening CLs MHPSS capacities and ensure (relative) staff well-being.

title.narrative: Education in Emergencies Response to Beirut Blast (CHILD)

description.narrative: MEHE rapid needs assessment conducted with the technical support of UNICEF and released on the 20th August 2020 indicates approximately 160 schools affected and disruption of learning to some 85,313 children and over 3,000 teachers.

The Beirut port explosion of the August 4, 2020 has caused widespread damage and casualties. In a radius of 24 km, up to 300,000 persons lost their homes and were displaced. The education sector was heavily impacted, as the explosion led to the partial or complete destruction of approximately 160 public and private schools across Beirut and neighboring areas. Such devastation threatens to disrupt the 2020-21 academic year and deprive up to 85,000 Lebanese and non-Lebanese students of their right to education. The response will target affected schools and communities heavily affected by the blast. The intervention will be coordinated with the Lebanon’s Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE)1, UNESCO and UNICEF to avoid duplication.

The overall objective is to contribute to continuous access to and enhanced quality of education and protection services for children affected by the Beirut port explosion and the COVID-19 pandemic in Lebanon.

title.narrative: Mental Health Support and Cash Assistance after the Beirut Blast

description.narrative:
On 4 August 2020, at 18:00 (Beirut time), a warehouse at the Beirut Port containing 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate exploded. More than 160 deaths were reported, with an additional 5,000 persons injured, and more than 60 persons still missing. Hospitals have been overwhelmed with casualties as many ICUs were already reaching capacity with COVID-19 patients. The explosion also damaged countless buildings in Beirut. Multiple medical facilities, including several major hospitals, sustained structural damage. The Government of Lebanon estimates that the explosions have left more than 300,000 people homeless. Wide-spread trauma is reported by national partners.
The explosion has negatively impacted public psychosocial and mental health capacities in Lebanon, which were already diminished due to the economic crisis, devaluation of the national currency, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic: it is reported that three public psychiatric hospitals have stopped admitting patients, the two private hospitals, St. Georges Hospital and Hotel Dieu de France, were severely damaged and stopped admitting psychiatric patients.

The central objective of the project is that Syrian refugee and vulnerable Lebanese families in Burj Hammoud and Karantina are provided necessary services to respond to the immediate needs from the 04 August 2020 Beirut Explosion and begin the process of recovery

The target beneficiaries are Syrian refugee and vulnerable Lebanese families in Burj Hammoud and Karantina.
There are an estimated 8.950 direct beneficiaries.

title.narrative: Saving Lives Project Specific Indicators
Number of hygiene kits distributed
SHO Beirut explosion – Caritas Lebanon Emergency appeal

description.narrative: Cordaid's pledge will contribute to the overall objective of the project, which is: Responding to the humanitarian needs of those affected by the Beirut Blast. The provided funds will support Caritas Lebanon in achieving their objectives of 1) Affected Lebanese HH and individuals are secured and meet their most critical needs; 2) 13,000 of impacted people have their medical status maintained; 3) 420 Impacted Lebanese students have access to E-learning education for the upcoming scholastic year 2020-21; 4) 150 Impacted Lebanese households feel safe and secure again in their own houses; 5) 40 Impacted Lebanese businesses are recovering from the blast and ready to retrieve their activities (ready to regenerate money).
Impacted Lebanes Households and Students

On August 4th, a large explosion occurred in the Beirut port, killing over 175 and injuring over 6,500 people. Rescue efforts continue to find those who are still missing. The exact cause of the blast is pending investigation, but so far, it has been linked to 2,750 tons of confiscated ammonium nitrate.
Around 300,000 people have lost their homes and are in need of shelters, food, and medicines. The majority of displaced people are poor families, migrants and refugees living in underdeveloped areas. People have also lost their jobs, businesses, shops, restaurants, hotels, and public buildings.
The physical and mental health needs of families is already overwhelming. The psychological effect is massive, especially among children who have witnessed the destruction of their homes or family members injured. The explosion has also exacerbated the immense psychological distress caused by food insecurity, COVID-19, and the economic and political crises.
Cordaid has pledged to support Caritas Lebanon in their Emergency Appeal project in response to the Beirut explosion.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Non-formal education
EDU-I2: Number of boys and girls that access safe, quality learning opportunities (non-formal education)

description.narrative: Quality implies but is not limited to: 1) a safe learning environment, 2) competent and well-trained teachers who are knowledgeable in the subject matter, 3) adequate materials for teaching and learning, 4) participatory methods of instruction and 5) reasonable class sizes. Especially in complex emergencies, the quality of education is closely interlinked with learners’ psycho-social wellbeing. Safe implies: people’s physical and personal wellbeing and integrity as well as to their freedom from physical, environmental, social, spiritual, political, emotional and psychological harm.

CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

Syria Joint Response 2021

description.narrative: Syria remains one of the largest and most complex humanitarian emergencies in the world today. Overall, an estimated 11.1 million people need some form of humanitarian assistance in 2020, including 4.7 million people in acute need. Economic shocks coupled with the direct and indirect impact of COVID-19 stand to further increase the number of people in need during the remainder of 2020 and beyond. According to WFP, almost half the population – some 9.3 million Syrians – are now estimated to be food insecure, an increase of 1.4 million in just the last six months. Not only that, but the number of people severely food insecure – that is those going to bed hungry – has almost doubled from around 570,000 to just over a million. From an economic standpoint, at least, things have never been worse. Health needs in Syria are already significant. Thousands of children are suffering from severe malnutrition. Thousands of more people suffer from cancer, diabetes, and other chronic conditions for which treatment is limited. More than 12 million people (out of the total estimated population of 20 million) are in need of health care services in 2020. 70% of the sub-districts (188 out of 268) have very severe health needs and a severity score of 3 or above. The areas of most concern are densely populated areas, notably Rural Damascus and Aleppo.
To saving lives and increasing resilience and access to services.
vulnerable people

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

CARJR7 -Member

description.narrative: As indicated in the above paragraphs, the targeted prefectures and sub-prefectures are characterized by the return of people who left their villages and localities because of the crisis. Thus, the beneficiaries of the activities planned in this proposal will be internal returnees, repatriates from neighboring countries, and their host families. In case of the presence of IDP sites/camps or at least IDPs in host families, the latter will also be considered as primary beneficiaries. Depending on their vulnerability, host families will also be considered beneficiaries. Beyond the status and within the latter, women and girls who are heads of households without support, women and girls living alone and without support, widows and widowers who are heads of households without support, people living with disabilities and without support, the elderly, and families with malnourished children.

The Central African Republic is going through a deep crisis characterized by generalized insecurity caused by - the presence and activism of armed groups, - inter-community and religious tensions, - the issue of transhumance, - the weak presence of state services at the local level, - the contestation of the electoral process, - bad governance, etc. This being the case, the country continues to face a serious protection crisis, despite the signing of the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation on February 6, 2019. As a result, civilians continue to pay the highest price for the violence. It is estimated that more than half of the population, or 2.6 million people, are in need, of which 1.7 million are in acute need of humanitarian assistance, half of whom are children (HNO 2020). One in four Central Africans have been forced to flee due to insecurity and threats, and an estimated 658,929 people are internally displaced as of July 31, 2020. In addition, the Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated the vulnerabilities of the most marginalized groups. Unfortunately, communities have shown resistance to the humanitarian response to Covid-19, as there is mistrust and misconceptions that it is a "stranger's disease" concentrated in Bangui, when it may not exist outside the capital. The challenges of access to water remain enormous. Only 68% of the country's water needs are not covered and 70% of sanitation needs are not covered, which places the country among the least developed in the world. The different population movements have not allowed the population to cultivate during the agricultural season A 2020: they live to 90% of the products of the fields, for food and as sources of income. Thus, more than ¾ of the population is in phase 3+ (crisis) with a probability of slipping to phase 4 (emergency) and 5 (famine) if no assistance is provided and stability guaranteed.
To contribute to human lives saving, respect of fundamental rights and the preservation of human dignity.

title.narrative: Solid waste management
WSH-I5: Number of people living in settlements with a functional solid waste management system

description.narrative: Solid waste of all households of the settlements as well as commercial waste is removed stored safely and removed regularly with equipment and frequency according to standards (Sphere). Risk of solid waste pollution of environment is kept to a minimum. Medical waste is managed separately according to standards to minimize risk. System implies: planning and implementation in consultation with affected populations and relevant authorities, taking into account refuse type and quantity, incl. medical, burial, market etc; adequate disposal with minimum risk; attention to staff welfare.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Winterization assistance in Afghanistan (Ghor) and Syria (Lattakia)

description.narrative:
After many years of continued crisis, Afghanistan and Syria remain among the world’s most complex humanitarian emergencies, driven by escalating conflict and devastating natural disasters. Depleted resilience to cope with the repeated shocks of displacement and conflict/ natural disaster have made it difficult for households to withstand the harsh winter condition, where monthly temperatures can reach as low as -12.1 degrees Celsius. Even under normal circumstances, it is difficult for households to meet their basic needs and their vulnerability is further exasperated by the harsh winter conditions. Unfortunately, people’s dire situation was already exacerbated by COVID-19 prior to winter. COVID-19 has caused loss of employment, sharp price increase of basic (food) items resulting in a steep rise in acute food insecurity and malnutrition. The insufficient/ inadequate health systems in the countries cannot cope with higher demands in winter because of COVID-19. Women, children, elderly and the (chronically) ill and the disabled are bearing the brunt of the crises in the two countries. Without support, winter will increase their vulnerabilities further.
Because of the protracted humanitarian crises in both countries and recurrent harsh winters, Cordaid Afghanistan and Syria recognized the need for a winterization strategy, incorporated in its humanitarian strategy and delivery of humanitarian assistance in both countries.
Multi- Shock affected

The overall objective of the project is to reduce the suffering and improve the living conditions and dignity of most vulnerable people during winter by providing winterization assistance. Additionally, the project aims share experiences between Afghanistan and Syria and to collect recommendations and inform the Cordaid Joint Winterization Strategy 2021-2022.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Ethiopia Tigray Conflict response

description.narrative: In consultation and coordination with UNOCHA, and the relevant clusters, APDA will target 7,500 most vulnerable households who have been affected by the conflict. For beneficiary targeting the cluster standards will be used. Criteria for beneficiary selection include: · IDPs, returnees, · Women (23% of the affected population according to the humanitarian preparedness plan) · Children (50.4% of the affected population according to the humanitarian preparedness plan) · Elderly headed households; · Physically disabled headed households; 8% of the affected population according to the humanitarian preparedness plan) · Households with persons with special needs (PSN) including PWD, PLW, chronically ill people; · Households with no basic items /or those who have lost most of their properties while fleeing.

The humanitarian situation in Tigray region is highly tense and volatile, with thousands of people reportedly lacking access to assistance since the conflict erupted on November 4th. This crisis comes at a time Ethiopia is grappling with a dire humanitarian situation caused by displacement, desert locust infestation, food insecurity and impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The UN and humanitarian organizations continue to be extremely concerned about the safety and welfare of civilians in Tigray region, including more than 500,000 citizens and 200 aid workers currently in Mekelle where fighting is likely to escalate. Access to the Tigray region is limited, and information on needs is mostly based on estimations and projections. However, as of 24 November 2020, on top of the 850,000 people already dependent on some type of humanitarian assistance in Tigray, UNOCHA is projecting 1.1 million additional people in need due to the conflict in Tigray and neighbouring Amhara and Afar regions. Another 43,000 people have fled to East Sudan, UNHCR is preparing to cater to the needs of at least 100,000 refugees in the coming period (UNHCR regional updates 25-27 November). Moreover, there is an underfunding of the Humanitarian Preparedness Plan has an outstanding requirement of 75.6 Million USD.
To provide emergency response to address the needs of people in Tigray and IDPs in neighbouring Afar regions.

description.narrative:
Cordaid et son partenaire SOPADI, ont mené et/ou participé à plusieurs évaluations sectorielles et multisectorielles de besoins. Il s'agit i) évaluation multisectorielle menée du 5 au 10 Septembre 2019 sous le lead de OCHA sur l'axe Dimbi-Setema et à Satema Centre, ii) l'évaluation de besoins sectorielle menée du 13 au 17 août et du 9 au 27 août dans sous-préfectures de Mingala, Mobaye et Axe Alindao Bokolobo, Poudjio Boy kette, iii) une évaluation de besoins multisectorielle menée sous le lead de OCHA dans la sous-préfecture de Alindao et la commune de Kotto en sous-préfecture de Mingala du 14 au 16 Septembre 2020. Pour la rédaction du présent projet, Cordaid a également consulter le rapport de dénombrement/recensement effectué par A.S.A gestionnaire des sites des PDIs à Alindao en Septembre 2020. Les résultats de toutes ces évaluations et consultations, ont révélé les besoins criants dans les secteurs de l'éducation et de l’eau, hygiène et assainissement en plus de la protection. Plusieurs écoles sont non fonctionnelles, pillées et/ou incendiées, les maitre parents démotivés et/ou peu qualifiés, certains parents appauvris par les crises pour la plupart, n'ont pas la possibilité d'envoyer les enfants à l'école en particulier les filles. A titre illustratif, sur la 44 école existante dans la sous-préfecture de Zangba, seules 27 écoles sont opérationnelles. On compte 122 maitres parents, sur 10 183 élèves (avec une ration de 7 080 garçons et 3 103 filles) . Ces chiffres se réfèrent aux inscriptions de l’année 2019-2020. En matière d'accès à l'eau, d’hygiène et d’assainissement, la situation sur les 4 sites abritant les personnes déplacées internes à Alindao, les infrastructures d'approvisionnement en eau restent à maintenir et renforcer ; il existe un besoin de recycle et monitorer le niveau des sensibilisateurs pour assurer la mise en place des activités collectives lies á la promotion de l’hygiène. Dans les écoles, cette situation est encore plus complexe. Presque toutes les écoles fonctionnelles n’ont des latrines hygiéniques ni des systèmes de gestion des déchets. Les élèves et enseignants, font leurs besoins dans la brousse à l’air libre ; exposant ainsi les élèves et en particulier les filles aux violences sexistes et entame leur intimité. 90% des élèves et leurs /familles, ne connaissent et/ou n’appliquent pas les bonnes pratiques d’hygiènes en particulier les 5 moments de lavage des mains. Plus de 70% d'élève, ne croient pas à l’existence de la pandémie du COVID 19 et/ou n’appliquent pas les gestes barrières et la distanciation physique. De même, bien que situé non loin de la frontière de la RDC, ces élèves et PDI, ne connaissent et/ou ni croient à l'existence de la maladie virale d'Ebola. Tant au niveau de 4 sites de personnes déplacées internes que dans les écoles, les notions sur la santé sexuelle et reproductifs en particulier l'hygiène menstruelle des filles, ne sont pas ni connues, ni vulgarisées. Ces notions, restent en grande partie, considérées comme un tabou dans la zone.
Les sous-préfectures de Zangba, Satéma et Mingala, sont à ce jour, considérées comme des zones de retour. Plus de 50% de population est déjà retourné. L’amélioration de la sécurité dans ces zones, a permis ces mouvements de retour. La sous-préfecture d'Alindao quant à elle, est considérée comme une zone mixte car abritant les sites de personnes déplacées internes estimé à 20694 individus (récemment de Septembre 2020). Malheureusement, pour des multiples raisons et en comparaison aux besoins existants, peu d’acteurs humanitaires sont présents dans ces zones.

Le présent projet, se veut une réponse multisectorielle et intégrée visant à contribuer à sauver des vies et soulager les souffrances, assurer la survie des filles et des garçons (3-18 ans) à travers un accès équitable et inclusif à des environnements d’apprentissage sains et sûrs en faveurs de personnes affectées et/ou exposées à l’insécurité et aux mouvements de populations, aux inondations, aux différentes épidémies y inclus la COVID 19 dans les sous-préfectures de Satéma, Zangba, Alindao et Mingala dans la préfecture de Basse Kotto. Ces zones, sont parmi celles où l’accès humanitaire a été récemment rendu possible et donc ayant très peu ou pas, bénéficiées de l’assistance humanitaire ; ce qui le classe en zone, 4 ou 5 selon l’échelle de sévérité dans presque tous les secteurs de la vie. Les activités proposées dans le présent projet, seront mises en œuvre par un consortium de deux organisations. Cordaid étant lead et Solidarité pour la Paix et la Développement intégré (SOPADI); une organisation internationale basée à Bangui. Les deux organisations possèdent une expertise et expérience dans la mise en œuvre des activités dans les domaines de l'éducation et de l'eau, hygiène et assainissement. Les activités proposées dans le présent projet, s’articulent autour de deux secteurs clés à savoir: A. Education (à Zangba et Satema) Pour ce secteur, les activités s'articulent autour de i) sensibilisation de la communauté à travers la formation des 90 représentants des associations des parents d'élèves et 15 relais communautaires, ii) l'organisation des 96 campagnes de sensibilisation des parents et communautés sur le droit à l’éducation des enfants sur le retour à l'école en particulier des filles et les minorités; iii) la mise en place et équipement de 7 écoles satellites ainsi que l'appui à la réouverture de 3 anciennes écoles incluant l'appui aux secteurs scolaires de Zangba et Satéma, pour le suivi des activités mises en œuvre dans le cadre du présent projet, iv) la distribution de 750 Kits scolaire (19 Scholl box de 40 kits) y incluse la distribution de 30 Kits récréatif; v) le recrutement de 25 nouveaux maitres parents et leur dotation en matériels didactique et leur formation sur la pédagogie, l'appui psychosociale, la cohésions sociale ainsi que la méthodologie de cour de rattrapage et les mesures de lutte contre la COVID 19; vi) l'appui monétaire (motivation en Cash) de 25 maitre parents et enseignants; vii) l'appui monétaire (transfert de Cash) aux 375 parents les plus vulnérable pour la scolarisation; viii) la construction de 10 blocs de latrine VIP, le creusage de 10 fosses (une par école), la distribution des Kits d'hygiène intime à 100 élèves filles dans les 10 écoles, la formation des 10 Clubs d'hygiène et 25 enseignants sur les notions d'hygiène et la gestions des infrastructures WASH en milieu scolaire et familiale.
B. Eau, Hygiène et assainissement (Alindao et Mingala) Pour ce secteur, les activités s'articulent autour de i) l'approvisionnement en eau potable, la gestion des déchets et ordures solides, la promotion à 'hygiène dans les sites des PDI à Alindao, à travers le maintien et renforcement des capacités de 25 points de distribution d'eau, la gestion des déchets solides (vidange de boue des latrines plaines, ramassage des déchets et ordures), construction des 30 latrines et 30 douches, la promotion de meilleures pratiques d'hygiène et assainissement à travers les hygiénistes, 10 relais communautaires; ii) la construction 6 blocs de latrines dans 6 écoles fonctionnelles (3 portes chacun), la distribution des Kits d'hygiène intime/menstruels à 72 élèves filles (en âge de procréer), la distribution de 72 dispositifs de lavage des mains, 72 dispositifs d'eau de boisson dans les 6 écoles (primaires et collège) à Alindao et Mingala, le recyclage et l'équipement de 15 relais communautaires, la formation de 36 enseignants sur les meilleures pratiques d'hygiènes et d'assainissement en milieu scolaire et familiale, Motiver 10 agents d'approvisionnement en eau Chloré des DLM sur les sites pour prévention covid
des filles et des garçons (3-18 ans)

participating-org.narrative: UNOCHA - United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Saving lives in Jonglei

description.narrative: 1. people have access to immediate food assistance and their livelihoods are restored: 2. people have access to safe and sufficient drinking water and improved hygiene 3. people have access to basic Shelter and Non-Food items 4. Accountability mechanisms and PSN referrals and support established

In consultation and coordination with UNOCHA, RRC, and all the clusters, Cordaid will target the most vulnerable households. For beneficiary targeting the cluster standards will be used. Criteria for beneficiary selection include: • Children • Women headed households. • Child headed households. • Elderly headed households and persons with specific needs (PSN) such as HH with chronically ill, PWD, PLW. • Type of shelter and condition the beneficiaries are being accommodate in now. Households with no basic items /or those who have lost most of their properties during the flooding.

Jonglei is one of the severely affected states in South Sudan with 404,000 people in need of humanitarian assistance and another 125,000 are affected in the Greater Pibor area. Nine Counties in Jonglei (Twic East, Pibor, Pochalla, Ayod, Uror, Nyirol, Bor South, Duk and Pigi Canal) are the most affected by the floods resulting into displacement of 368,000 people into highland areas, 26,892 Ha of cereals farms destroyed and 11,915 Tons of estimated cereal loss. In addition, an estimated 711,400 animals (Cattles, Goats, Sheep) disappeared or displaced with no access to pastures as grasslands and shrublands are submerged under water with an increased risk of starvation deaths which has resulted into 47,555 reported animal deaths. Compounding shocks from sub-national violence, covid-19 and flooding have severely affected a state that was still recovering from previous flooding in 2019. Following the floods, the majority of Jonglei is declared in IPC 4 with pockets of catastrophe IPC5 in the January 2020 IPC analysis as people will miss the planting seasons since the water is not going down in time for the planting season. Bor South and Canal/ Pigi county are two of the nine most affected counties in Jonglei state. In Bor South (Bor) 150,000 people have been affected and displaced by the floods and in Canal/ Pigi County, 78,000 people have been displaced. 191 tons of cereal production lost (32% of total county production) and 5,286 reported total number of animals that died amongst 72,366 affected animals. The impact of the flood exacerbates on the IPC 4 July-September projections of Bor and Canal/Pigi County. In addition, the flood has displaced thousands of people with women and children the most affected, houses are destroyed, properties lost, and water infrastructures are made unsafe for drinking. The lack of shelter and safe and sufficient drinking water is a major public health risk, as people cannot protect themselves against the weather and waterborne diseases are on the rise. There is also a spike in malarial cases. Women, children, elderly and disabled are disproportionately affected by the floods, violence, and displacement, making them extremely vulnerable for (S)GBV increasing their protection needs. Despite efforts to assist the people from some of the affected counties, in Bor some 10,000 HH (60,000 people) have not received any aid and no assistance has reached people of Canal/ Pigi County to date. As such, 138,000 people are in immediate need of food assistance as well as seeds and fishing gears to allow them to rebuild their livelihoods. Household water treatment products including WASH NFIs are needed as well, to ensure immediate access to safe drinking water as water infrastructures are being restored. People also need Shelter and non-food items to ensure proper shelter and protection against weather, reducing protection risks of women, girls, boys and the elderly who are disproportionately affected. Lack of proper shelter and non-food items have seen rise in many cases of pneumonia, Rheumatoid and Malaria among the elderly and children. Furthermore, 96% of the people are using unprotected water sources as their main sources of drinking water has been contaminated or destroyed by the raging floods and in assessed areas no latrines were available (REACH June 2020). The lack of safe drinking water and sanitation facilities is a major public health risk with a looming outbreak of cholera or other waterborne diseases.
In summary people are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance for their survival including emergency shelter and NFIs (tarpaulins, ropes), food and emergency livelihood support and safe drinking water and sanitation. This project will therefore, aim to reach 64,800 most vulnerable people affected by the multiple shocks in Bor South County and Canal/Pigi County with emergency life-saving assistance as other sources of funding through coordination with different clusters is sought to address the needs in these locations.

title.narrative: Addressing food crises in Afghanistan

description.narrative: Cordaid/RRAA will specifically target vulnerable groups who are in either IPC 3 or 4. For identification of such beneficiaries Cordaid will use the cluster standard tool (food consumption score card) to obtain information regarding the food consumption score and coping strategies. Selected beneficiaries have low food consumption scores and high coping strategies. In addition, these vulnerable groups include women, children, the elderly, disabled and chronically ill, persons with special needs.

The humanitarian situation in Afghanistan continues to decline in late 2020, characterized by high levels of ongoing violence and conflict caused by the stalled peace process, natural disasters including floods and winter, high rates of poverty with most of the population (30.5M of the 40M people) lacking and financial security, contributing to a worsening grave protection crisis, causing significant displacement and high multi-sector needs across the country. According the 2021 HRP 18.4M Afghans need humanitarian assistance which is 46% of the population. People are characterized by low resilience and high vulnerabilities and often fall into a state of acute emergency and need urgent support to meet their immediate basic needs. The COVID-19 pandemic has had and continues to have a significant acute impact across Afghanistan and exacerbated already high levels of multi-sector needs for vulnerable communities due to loss of livelihoods and income, and reduced access to essential services as a result of government-imposed lockdowns, movement restrictions and market volatility, which has eroded coping mechanisms and increased negative coping strategies.
Within this context, food insecurity remains severe across Afghanistan, and which has worsened due to COVID-19 and conflict. Most notably, the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is having a devastating impact on people’s livelihoods and income, and coupled with chronic underlying poverty, has already started to further challenge families’ capacity to purchase essential food supplies. The lockdown and restrictions of mobility has had a negative impact on both the supply chain for basic commodities as well as on household livelihood and income opportunities, subjecting vulnerable households to reduced income, higher prices of food commodities, and reduced access to food due to supply chain disruptions. According to the latest IPC assessments, 7 of the 34 provinces are worse off and in IPC4. Over the past 3 months the food security situation deteriorated, with an additional 388,000 people in IPC4, totalling the number of people in IPC4 nearly 1.5M (IPC Nov 2020). One of the worst affected provinces is Uruzgan province, which is specifically facing this worsening situation. The latest IPC analysis projects Uruzgan as escalating to IPC Phase 4 (Emergency) from November 2020 to March 2021, with 140,000 people in IPC 4 in addition to the approx. 140,000 in IPC3 (IPC Nov 2020), which is 50% of the population in the province.
The overall objective of the project is to increase access to food to multiple shock affected people who are in IPC phase 3 or phase 4 in Uruzgan.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Ethiopia Tigray Joint Response (ETJR)

description.narrative:
A total of 3,778 beneficairies will receive food and Shelter supports by the two local partners(EOC-DICAC and Caritas Ethiopia). 2000 people will be supported food items and 1,778 people will get Shelter Items(NFIs). All partners and their local implementing partners have agreed to follow the same five guiding rules for beneficiary selection and targeting.
Beneficiaries are selected through involvement of local government, community elders and partners, selecting the most vulnerable through agreed criteria. Selection criteria of most vulnerable are in line with cluster guidelines and include: - Female Headed Household; - Child Headed Household; - Disabled Headed Household; - Elderly Headed Household with no adults having an income;
Provide life-saving assistance to people facing severe acute needs.

Since the conflict between a federal military force and the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), thousands of people’s lives has been impacted and worsening the already poor humanitarian situation. At least 222,413 people are internally displaced as a result of the conflict, while 58,334 people have fled into neighboring Sudan (UNHCR, 2020). Additionally, at least 63,000 have been displaced within Amhara and Afar (UNICEF, 2021). According to the Emergency Coordination Center (ECC) 4,5 million people need direct food assistance as a result of insecurity on imports and the harvest. Before the conflict started, a total of 507,000 already received food assistance.
Two months since the start of the conflict in Tigray, the humanitarian situation continues to critically deteriorate. Dire shortages of the most basic supplies, including food, water, fuel and cash affect the whole region, leading to a looming humanitarian catastrophe. With access to water, sanitation & health services seriously disrupted, humanitarians warned about the heightened risk of water-borne & vector-borne diseases, as well as COVID-19. The situation in and around the four refugee camps, which together host 96,000 refugees, is absolutely dire. Many people, including 5 NGO staff members, were killed during the horrific atrocities that took place during attacks (UN OCHA, 2021). Despite declaring the completion of the war, fighting continues and the situation in Tigray remains extremely volatile. Sporadic fighting in rural areas is reported on a weekly and sometimes even daily basis. The security situation is dire, especially in peripheral areas and villages around Mekelle, where looting and other incidents are still occurring. Despite the challenging security environment, humanitarians continue to deliver limited assistance with available resources and in the limited areas where access is relatively permissive.

title.narrative: DRC Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: The DRCJR 2020 will aim to provide multi-sectoral assistance and sustainable solution in response to community-identified life-saving needs and protection risks through close collaboration and coordination in the Eastern Zone of DRC.
The World Vision programming focuses on Education, WASH and Protection. It also includes a COVID-19 top up.

The overall target group of the DRCJR 2020 has not been changed (compared to the DRCJR 2019), as the JR partners continue to focus on the most vulnerable and conflict affected people within the targeted Health Zones. With the collaboration moved to Health Zone level, the JR partners will conduct a joint vulnerability mapping or needs assessment to identify the most vulnerable areas in the HZ and/or agree on a set of target criteria. This will be validated (and revised) by members of the target communities.

North West Syria Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: Shelter and cash assistance and COVID-19 prevention to IDPs
Through this project, a total of 600 households, 3600 IDPs (720 women, 1,152 girls, 684 men and 1,044 boys) will be targeted in Dana sub-district, Harem.

WV and IYD will install 600 tents with ground insulation to newly displaced households (HH). Tents will be provided to HH’s without shelter or HHs who reside in overcrowded shelters (defined by Sphere). HHs will receive a 120 USD unrestricted grant. To complement this action the FAST consortium will provide core NFI kits, WV will provide hygiene dignity kits that do not form part of these. In addition, WASH activities and health promotion will be carried out to tackled COVID-19.

Lebanon Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: On 4 August 2020, a massive warehouse exploded in Beirut harbor, triggering a shockwave that damaged several major hospitals, numerous businesses and houses in the Greater Beirut area, leaving more than 300,000 people homeless and livelihoods threatened (UNOCHA). The explosion hits Lebanon as it faces a multi-faceted crisis, featuring economic contraction, increasing poverty, inflation and exposure to COVID-19. The pressure on already overwhelmed hospitals and social tensions have compounded needs among Lebanese people as well as refugees. The blast has directly affected the source of income of many households already hit by COVID-19 lockdown measures. Access to food is a concern as Lebanon is heavily dependent on imports from the port.

WV and DAA prioritize reaching HHs who have been affected by the explosion. WVI has set criteria to identify and reach the most vulnerable children, including orphans, refugee/IDP children as well as children under the care of vulnerable adults. WV closely coordinates with local organizations, partners, and municipalities to facilitate its outreach process. WV also targets children and/or HHs reaching its hotline number, making sure their residency area and relevancy of their needed services. For food distributions, WV assesses HHs based on their vulnerability. These mainly include HHs located near to the site of the blast which contain elderly, disabled, children, pregnant or lactating women. In order to make sure that non-Lebanese are not excluded from beneficiaries due to a bias within lists shared by various local entities, WV has included a possibility of self-referral.

WV and partner Dar Al Amal (DAA) aim to respond to immediate needs of most vulnerable girls, women, boys and men of host and refugee communities affected by the Beirut explosion through an integrated project. WV distributes in-kind food parcels to vulnerable households so that they are able to meet the Survival Minimum Expenditure Basket (SMEB). This is the preferred modality due to the current economic situation coupled with temporary unavailability of products in markets nearby affected HHs. Food parcels are designed in alignment with FS standards, covering most of the energy needs for HH of 5 members over 1 month. Each HH receives one parcel. Vulnerable HH have been pre-identified in districts affected by the blast in alignment with vulnerability criteria set by the FS sector. WV and DAA distribute personal hygiene kits to 1,000 HHs in order to protect affected HHs from COVID-19 spread and transmission, and reach 5,000 people through hygiene promotion and awareness raising, incl. prevention of COVID-19. The originally planned activity of water storage tanks distribution has been replaced by extra food parcels, as the needs for water trucking were minimal, as opposed to the needs for direct food assistance. WV and DAA support the psychological wellbeing of affected HHs, providing PFA, either face to face or remotely, to children and their caregivers affected by the explosion. CP/PSS activity sheets and PSS kits with age appropriate sessions and activities are distributed to ensure children receive appropriate psychosocial care. Caregivers and community groups receive CP and MHPSS messages and feedback on their progress through WhatsApp. After capacity-building, WV works along with DAA to provide remote PSS to caregivers through group calls, which are set up based on National and WV guidance note. Through coordination with other organizations, WV and DAA refer cases in need of specialized services and provide emergency cash assistance for transportation to these services.

South-Sudan COVID-19 Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: All project staff before deployment undergoes a training on Accountability to Affected Population (AAP), HR systems, PSEA, Code of Conduct and Do No Harm. The community will be briefed on the same and required to provide feedback through an agreed and appropriate beneficiary feedback mechanism. Target communities will be engaged through the project cycle and beneficiaries disaggregated based on their level of vulnerability. Due to protracted communal conflicts in T.N, women and children have been significantly affected by armed conflict and continued displacement, resulting in limited access to services. The project is sensitive to ensure that women, children, elderly and persons living with disabilities (PLWD) are included while mainstreaming protection monitoring especially for women and girls on SGBV. For WASH the project will take into account both genders (committees), elderly and PLWD (design ensure access) and children in schools, health centres and other public places.

Soap and handwashing facilities are being distributed among 8 schools (4800 children) and 4 Primary Health Care Centers (PHCC) with high patient volumes (1.200 patient visits per facility per month) in combination with hygiene promotion messages. In addition, 14 non-functional handpumps are being rehabilitated and all 16 technicians of T.N are being trained on maintenance. To enhance proper water management and also enforce the COVID-19 restrictions as opposed by the government, the water user committees are trained (126 people; >30% women). At the PHCC level the focus is on increasing the primary health consultation through engagement of Boma Health Workers (BHWs) linked to the 4 PHCCs. BHWs (80) will be trained on COVID-19 prevention, and is incentivized for referral of clients for curative services. The 4 PHCCs are being equipped to provide service delivery through employment of 2 clinical officers and 4 registered nurses. This increases the capacity of the PHCCs to treat patients. In addition, 60 health workers are equipped with PPE and trained on how to offer curative services during this COVID-19 pandemic. Four temporary shelters and 200 benches will be constructed at each of the PHCC to allow social distancing following the MoH guidelines. Two friendly spaces for women and children are constructed and volunteers are trained to provide protection prevention messages. The project’s social workers are guiding these women and children to engage in life skills activities and at the same time create awareness around forced marriage, child marriage and other SGBV issues and distribute PEP kits to survivors. Community action teams and volunteers receive training and support to conduct monitoring visits and prevention messaging (integrating info on COVID-19) in 5 payams in T.N to offer referral guidance to those in need. There is a case manager offering PSS in the friendly spaces.

The COVID-19 outbreak in South Sudan comes against the backdrop of an already dire humanitarian situation, since 7.5 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance (HNO, 2020). Tonj North (T.N), a county with a COVID Risk of 4,33/10, has to deal with inter-communal clashes on top of the COVID-19 thread. WASH: only 38% of the households in South Sudan reported having access to safe water. According to an assessment done in February 2020 in T.N 220 out of the 350 handpumps are non-functional due to the lack of spare parts and poor maintenance. Women and girls have to walk approximately 3km to the nearest water point and these sources are often crowded increasing the risk of being exposed to Covid-19. In addition, there is limited access to hand washing facilities both at household levels and at public places. Health: 56% of the population of South Sudan does not have access to primary health care services. Out of the 2.300 facilities more than 1.300 are non-functional (HNO, 2020). Available health centers are overcrowded, and are lacking both PPE, materials and supplies to treat patients. Protection: 7.5 million South Sudanese are in need of emergency assistance while 1.85 million of these (25%) require GBV support (HNO, 2020). Schools are closed since March 2020 and children are at increased risk of becoming a victim of GBV. On top of this over 95,000 in T.N are displaced as a result of the communal conflicts. Tonj North is one of the priority locations for GBV (HRP June ’20). World Vision (WV) in partnership with The Organisation for Children Harmony (TOCH) focuses on an integrated response to increase the access to safe water (rehabilitation of 14 water sources), distribution of soap, and hand washing facilities in schools and health facilities; increase the capacity of health workers’ access to necessary supplies and equipment to prevent the spread of COVID-19; and increase the capacity to deliver adequate SGBV and psychosocial support.

DRC Joint Response 2020 (Lead)

description.narrative: The DRCJR 2020 will aim to provide multi-sectoral assistance and sustainable solution in response to community-identified life-saving needs and protection risks through close collaboration and coordination in the Eastern Zone of DRC.

The overall target group of the DRCJR 2020 has not been changed (compared to the DRCJR 2019), as the JR partners continue to focus on the most vulnerable and conflict affected people within the targeted Health Zones. With the collaboration moved to Health Zone level, the JR partners will conduct a joint vulnerability mapping or needs assessment to identify the most vulnerable areas in the HZ and/or agree on a set of target criteria. This will be validated (and revised) by members of the target communities.

Desert Locusts Joint Response - Lead

description.narrative: The current locust crisis in the Horn of Africa is the worst outbreak of locusts in over 25 years in Ethiopia and Somalia and the worst observed in over 70 years in Kenya. The situation rapidly deteriorated in January 2020 as weather conditions have been unusually conducive to the spread of the pest. These conditions will allow breeding until June 2020 and could lead to 500 times more locusts, with the formation of large numbers of swarms. Desert locusts are expected to continue to breed and spread during the coming months. Given their life cycle, the March-April start of the long rains, coinciding with a regeneration of rangeland and the start of planting activities, will enable a new wave of breeding and further spread of the pest. Desert locusts have already reached northern Uganda, and looking forward, the infestation could: 1) spread further into the Rift Valley (especially in Ethiopia), as well as to South Sudan, 2) affect the 2020 main and secondary staple cropping seasons, and 3) continue to affect rangeland across the region. The desert locust is considered the most destructive migratory pest in the world as it is highly mobile and feeds on large quantities of any kind of green vegetation, including crops, pasture and fodder. A typical swarm can be made up of 150 million locusts per square kilometre and is carried on the wind, up to 150 km in one day. Even a very small, 1 km2 locust swarm (approx. 40 million desert locusts) can eat the same amount of food in one day as about 35 000 people. This can be especially devastating in areas where food security is poor and, where every gram of food produced counts towards minimizing gaps in a family’s food consumption. Currently, the region faces widespread food insecurity. In Ethiopia, an estimated 8.5 million people are severely food insecure, Phase 3 and above, according to IPC between February and June 2020. In Somalia, from February to September 2020, the population in IPC Phases 3 (Crisis) and 4 (Emergency) is expected to rise by 40 percent, from 1.1 million to 1.6 million people. Drivers of this food insecurity include climate shocks, conflict, and macroeconomic crises. Ethiopia has been responding to the current swarm invasions since July 2019. To date, hopper bands have covered more than 429 km² of the country. Two generations of breeding have caused large numbers of swarms to form and move to Kenya and Somalia. In January 2020, the swarms were also seen moving towards the Rift Valley in Ethiopia and Kenya’s breadbasket. This would pose a serious threat, especially as Ethiopia already has an estimated 8.5 million people facing severe food insecurity. In Somalia, where 6.7 million people are now regarded as acutely food insecure (IPC Phase 2 and above), swarms bred in the north of the country and have moved mainly to central and southern regions. The pest is affecting pasture and threatening staple food crops in rural areas. Insecurity and a lack of national capacity have hampered control operations. The Somalia Food Security Cluster showed their findings in a presentation; the number of people affected was shown as over 2.5 million (21% of Somalia’s population) and especially pastoralist, agro-pastoralist, riverine and IDPs are affected. COVID-19 In light of the global pandemic of COVID-19, on 25 March 2020, the United Nations launched a USD 2 billion Global Humanitarian Response Plan (GHRP). On 3 February, WHO also launched a Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SPRP). The following responses, corresponding with a locust crisis response, must be accelerated or scaled up to achieve Strategic Priorities 2 and 3 of the Covid-19 HRP: - Food and nutrition assistance as well as rural livelihood support to food-insecure and malnourished people vulnerable to the infection particularly in countries experiencing food crises. - Scale-up of social assistance systems, and cash transfer programmes with complementary livelihood assistance (including adaptations for remote digital trade/marketing), particularly for rural crop and livestock workers and producers, small/medium businesses, refugees, IDPs, migrants and host populations, and other food-insecure population groups. The Somalia section of the Covid-19 HRP mentions under the most affected and at-risk population groups that the pandemic could also heavily impact vulnerable communities living in areas dealing with food insecurity and desert locusts, while Ethiopia section mentions that COVID-19 response will undermine efforts to combat desert locust infestations. While people’s lives are threatened by the COVID-19 outbreak, the upcoming two agricultural production seasons are threatened by desert locust infestations. The number of COVID-19 cases reported in both Somalia (237) and Ethiopia (111) as of 20-04-2020 is still relatively low (also due to underreporting). Yet, the countries follow government restrictions and the response is designed with integrated COVID-10 measures.

title.narrative: Ethiopia Covid Joint Response - Lead

description.narrative:
The key objective of the Acute Joint Response is to provide lifesaving activities in response to COVID-19. The core activities per sector are described below.
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Food Security and Livelihoods • Drought-resistant and locally adaptable small ruminants to households whose livestock assets depleted due to COVID-19 induced restrictions • Small grants to support the start-up of Income Generating Activities for those whol have lost their livelihoods due to COVID-19 • Strengthen local economic initiatives through the provision of funding and support for Saving and Credit Groups • Provision of basic food items • Food vouchers in order to bridge the shortfalls in daily consumption
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to WASH • Provision of soap and hygiene kits to vulnerable households • Public spaces such as schools and market centers to be equipped with hand washing facilities • Rehabilitation of water points • Awareness raising and hygiene promotion focusing on C-19 prevention, including messages on SGBV, Mental health in the context of C-19 • Water trucking • Provision of water filters to vulnerable households • Latrine rehabilitation at treatment centers • Establishment of IPC services at treatment centers
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Health • Health centers will be rehabilitated and quarantine facilities will be set up • Mental Health consultations with (referred) people • Provisions of psychological first aid • Training on MHPSS for health workers • Peer group discussions on strengthening community awareness on MHPSS • Establishment of a mobile rapid response team (including health officer, epidemiologist, nurse, laboratory technologist, community health workers) • Verification of disease outbreak reports/rumours and appropriate measures for containment of the epidemic • Medical equipment including disinfectant chemicals and beds for health centers treating COVID-19 • Distribution of PPE for frontline health workers and beneficiaries, including hygiene awareness and C-19 training • Screening of <5 children and PLW for essential nutrition and communicable diseases
Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to Multi-Purpose Cash • Tear, SV/IRC and Cordaid provide unrestricted and unconditional cash to the most vulnerable households
Protection is not included as a stand-alone sector in this response, yet it is a central element of the intervention and mainstreamed throughout. The activities are designed in a way that is sensitive to age, gender and diversity.
Localization All DRA partners work with a local partners. Activities include: • Implement activities in all sectors. Including the provision of food for targeted communities, community engagement, beneficiary selection, distribution and implementation of WASH activities. • Facilitating C19-related MHPSS capacity building training to local government health workers • Providing training for volunteers and government staff on Child Protection and GBV prevention and referrals in the context of C19 • Implementing with OWDA and providing technical and organisation capacity building and support costs coverage. • Purchase and distribute PPE for frontline government health workers • Technical guidance to local partners • members of local government institutions and CSOs will involve in technical capacity building trainings, undertake joint project review, exchange knowledge and skills in high quality health service provision and project management • COVID-19 related MHPSS training to local government frontline health workers as part of the capacity building interventions
Accountability • Beneficiaries will be involved in initial project consultation sessions, Post Distribution Monitoring, and Post hygiene awareness surveys; Involve direct project beneficiaries in the needs identification, location selection and targeting; • Involve community WASH committees in the management and protection of water points; • Community volunteers and leaders of SHG will help coordinate implementation of both WASH and CASH activities.

participating-org.narrative: Stichting Beheer Subsidiegelden Dutch Relief Alliance

title.narrative: 2020 Ethiopia Covid Joint Response - Implementation SOS

description.narrative:
"Ethiopia is facing an unprecedented crisis due to the Covid-19 (C19) pandemic, compounded by a devastating desert locust invasion, widespread flooding and rising food prices. C19 is having an indirect and drastic impact on the food security situation throughout the country. A multisectoral assessment conducted in the Somali region shows that 75% of HHs have reduced their food consumption (Mercy Corps). Recent political unrest has caused many new internal displacements, resulting in overcrowded urban areas and informal settlements, which lack sufficient WASH infrastructure. Essential primary healthcare services have been reduced or suspended, meaning fewer mothers, women, girls and children < 5 can access routine treatment and/or other health services, including MHPSS. Women are especially vulnerable, often depending on the informal economy and lacking personal resources to cope with price increases. Access to healthcare is under threat due to fear of infection, increased caseload, lack of PPE and low staff capacity and training. Protection needs continue to rise, as cases of domestic abuse and SGBV have increased.
SOS Children’s Villages Ethiopia (SOS CVE) together with local partner OWDA will provide FSL, WASH and Health in Gode town, Kelafo, and Adadle woredas in the Shebele Zone -areas with high food insecurity (IPC3), where social and health services are mainly closed, and few other humanitarian actors are present. The intervention will focus on the provision of food via vouchers, hygiene promotion and awareness, critical WASH activities and primary health care services. The intervention will provide MHPSS (including treatment for SGBV victims) and improve the protection environment especially for children and women by mainstreaming protection across all activities. Coordinating with DRA members Oxfam, Plan and Dorcas, working in other zones of the Somali region, SOS CVE will offer health care referral services in order to maximise programme impact. "

title.narrative: 2021 DRA Central African Republic Joint Response 7

description.narrative:
According to the preliminary results of the needs assessment of CAR JR7, the livelihood needs as well as WASH needs are enormous in the sub-prefecture of Bangassou and Bakouma due to the poverty of the population and the security situation that the country has experienced since this long period. The education sector in Bossangoa and Bakouma is also neglected, as is the rest of the country, especially this year with the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to measures such as the closure of classrooms. According to the prefect of Bossangoa, given the vulnerability of their population, he is asking for the support of humanitarian partners in order to help improve the living conditions of his people who have suffered so much. Despite the interventions of humanitarian actors in this area, the needs in terms of child protection and food security remain a major challenge according to the Bangassou prefecture. The qualitative analysis of the data from the CAR-JR7 needs assessment indicates that children regularly face abuse, neglect, exploitation and sexual violence. Livelihood needs were also identified. For example, according to the inter-agency mission report, about 8294 people are acutely food insecure. Market-dependent households are the most affected. At the Mbomou level, particularly in Bangassou and Bakouma, SOS CV CAR intends to implement Protection and FSL activities through prevention and response as well as aspects related to gender-based violence and capacity building of community structures.
Thus in Bangassou, SOS CV CAR intends to strengthen its presence with local partners and community structures in the protection and promotion of children's rights. During our intervention within the framework of the JR6, the activities were implemented in partnership with the local NGO Vision Développement (VD), which has a very solid community base and which constitutes an important element in the implementation of our intervention strategy in the Bangassou area. In the JR7 we seek to strengthen this partnership via a larger program by the VD and an increased capacity strengthening of SOS CV CAR to VD. Through this partnership and training on child rights and protection, the Joint Response project will help to build and strengthen local protection committees (RECOPE), composed of women and men, including children themselves. These protection committees will help to prevent and respond to child rights violations, and to rebuild a more protective environment for children. The RECOPEs sharing their experiences is stimulated in order to accelerate ownership of the SOS VE protection strategy.
However in Bossangoa (Ouham prefecture) we will finalise the exit strategy that was started in the previous phase (JR6). Some limited scale of support will be given.

Yes I do Ethiopia incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off and forcing them to undergo FGM/C. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRH information and services. There are close links between EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw FGM/C is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies have similar root causes and these practices mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRH and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRH and given a voice to claim this information and these services. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRH and services. All these will help to reduce EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

Plan Ethopia focusses mainly on economic empowerment and education for girls ( pathway 4) with few community sensitization activities for an enabling environment under pathway 1. main activities: • Strengthen and support youth activist groups • Menstrual Hygiene Management at schools • Provide financial support and income generating activities for drop outs • Support girls clubs in school to create a safe and quality driven school environment. • Provide teacher training on Gender Responsive pedagogy

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Netherlands, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands Embassy in Addis Ababa and will be carried out in Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan as well.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies. Ethiopia was selected based upon on-going programmes of the alliance partners on FGM/C, EM and teenage pregnancies in the respective countries.
This will be worked out per country.

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. However- the political unrest impacted the administration of data collection- in Bahirdar Zuria nly 46% of the planned target- in Qewet it was possible to reach 100% target. This resulted in an overall coverage of 73% (1166 respondents) as compared to the planned target.
