title.narrative: Capacity training for policy makers
Number of capacity trainings delivered to policy makers (specify)

description.narrative: Different kind of policy makers are targeted : of health sector, justice sector, gvt involved with private sector and VERA agency responsible for birth registration system

comment.narrative: Number of capacity trainings delivered to policy makers (specify)

different kind of trainings: 1 for government officials who are involved with flower farm and other private sector on GBV; 1 for VERA agency on improving birth registration; 2 for different gvt agencies to increase knowledge on improving implementation of laws regarding FGM and CM

1 training was given for 15 government staff members on importance of measures against GBV in private sector companies. Two day workshop for 59 woreda and kebele duty bearers on the implementation of YIDA program and on issues CM, TP and FGM. Consultative workshop with 61 participants to enhance the knowledge and social behavior of key stakeholder on child protection issues, capitalize learning and linking among system of local governments, religious institutions, community structure; improve the child protection systems/ mechanisms and strengthen the documentation, monitoring and reporting of child protection concerns. Capacity building for 767 officials of different gvt and judiciary organisations on the importance of registration of vital events particularly birth registration to help prevent CM
Training of government staff members on child protection/GBV and decent work.

• In collaboration with BoWCYA and Bureau of Labour and Social Affairs, capacity building training provided for 39 (female: 5) participants comprised from government and (semi) private sectors ( Woreda Administrator, Investment office, Technical and Vocational Development office, Women, Children and Youth affairs office and flower farms). The training focused on GBV and decent work. • PIE in partnership with ECD organized a two days consecutive training on child protection issues for 72(Female: 19) government experts and FBOs leaders. The topics discussed during the training were CM, FGM, their legal frameworks, gender equality and how to build child protection systems and major strategies.

28 Community Conversation groups with 560 members (280 male, 280 female), 7 change agent groups, 15 youth activist gropus and 18 peer groups in local communities are created to address CM, TP and FGM and gender inequality
68 CC groups, 20 Iddir, 40 CoC and 10 Meharebe clubs,10 in-school girls clubs

68 CC groups, 20 Iddir, 40 CoC and 10 Meharebe clubs,10 in-school girls clubs Activities by these groups school based community members organized a school level campaign at Korebta kebele Salayish primary school and a total of 500 students including community members/parents (Female: 200 female) sensitized on child marriage and unsafe migration by school directors, club facilitator and kebele manager. • To act against HTPs (CM, FGM and TP) multi-stakeholder network is established at community level in 10 kebeles of Bahir Dar Zuria Woreda. The network is involved COC facilitators, CC facilitators, religious leaders, Iddir leaders, school principals, representatives of girls’ club kebele administrators • To capacitate and support the networks of CBOs, CSOs and nearby higher institutions aimed to advocate issues of SRH and promote gender equality a consultative meeting conducted with a CSO network named “Network for Action to Children, Girls and Young Women Empowerment’s” (NAGWE) which is established by 23 CSO working groups in Amhara Region with focus areas of child marriage, gender based violence and women economic empowerment. • Four events using March 8, Day of African child, world children day and women white ribbon day Issues of HTP particularly CM, FGM, TP as well as issues of vulnerable children and gender based violence were the main discussion agendas of the events. In those events, 795 (Female: 474) participants comprised from schools, youths, children and community members participated.

Contrary to previous years where the # of trained community groups were counted, these are networks of community groups The networks took different initiatives to reduce and bring promising behavioural change towards on CM, FGM and GBV issues. For instance, the groups established in the flower firms influenced the firms management and then 6 flower firms revised their HR and incorporated GBV/gender issues as a policy. The trained groups also established a firm committee to be the voice of girls and young women working in the firm as well the members of the groups take initiatives/commitment not to tolerate case of GBV and report it on timely manner.

17 schools (10 in Bahir Dar Zuria and 7 in Kewet) put in place child protection policy, safe and enabling environment for school children and adolescents girls. In addition girls’ advisory committees have been established, which comprised teachers, school girls and school principals, to advise and consult girls on social, economic, psychological and other issues like their educational performance improvement in and out of school environment. As the result girls in schools will be protected from any abuses both in school and their community and they will have better opportunity to report the cases and even cancel them.

title.narrative: WASH SDG Ethiopia (including COVID-19 prevention)

description.narrative:
Ethiopia has a population of 99.39 million people and is considered among the poorest countries in the world. In Bahir Dar Zuria and Lasta (Amhara region) hygiene and sanitation practice and service coverage is low and does not meet the basic level of standards. In most communities of those woredas, latrines are virtually non-existent and open defecation is still common practice. Many of the WASH entrepreneurs or producers have lost their interest in the WASH market due to lack of policy support and lack of financial sources. There is a lack of coordination between different WASH initiatives of the government, which effects the service delivery system in the WASH sector.
The communities in the program areas are patriarchal and little space is given to women to exercise their human rights. At community level women mostly do not have leadership roles. Economically poor girls use reusable home-made sanitary pads made of worn out cloths or apply nothing except putting on several dresses to control the menstrual discharge. In the communities, sanitary pads are not available. People with disabilities and people who by traditional religion are suspected of the evil eye are systematically excluded from community (WASH) decision making.
There is an increasing trend of drought and high temperature, flood, and erratic rainfall caused by climate change. This has already led to direct and indirect impacts on WASH services and infrastructures and will aggravate in future.

Financial sustainability means that continuity in the delivery of products and services related to WASH is assured, because the activities are locally financed (e.g. taxes, local fees, local credit products). Institutional sustainability means that WASH systems, institutions, policies and procedures at the local level are functional and meet the demand of users of WASH services. WASH stakeholders are clear on their own roles, tasks and responsibilities, are capable of fulfilling these roles effectively and are transparent to each other. The element of environmental sustainability implies placing WASH interventions in the wider context of the natural environment and implementing an approach of integrated and sustainable management of water and waste(-water) flows and resources, including the adaptation to climate change. Technical sustainability of WASH services is reached when the technology or hardware needed for continuous services is maintained, repaired and replaced by local people and it is not depleting the (natural) resources on which it depends for its functioning. Social sustainability refers to ensuring that the appropriate social conditions and prerequisites are realized and sustained so the current and future society is able to create healthy and liveable communities. Social sustainable intervention is demand-driven, inclusive (equality), gender equal, culturally sensitive and needs-based.

Pathway 1: By 2022 the programme wants in at least 30 communities in the target areas reach the open defecation free (ODF) status and people have moved up the sanitation and hygiene ladder. Women, girls and other socially excluded groups are empowered resulting in an increased level of participation of women/girls and other excluded groups in WASH activities in the community, shared WASH workload and decision making in the household and an increase level of leadership positions in communities around WASH. Fathers and mothers have improved their knowledge and practices about baby WASH and students, parents and teachers about MHM. Plan will enhance the capacity of the district offices to effectively use gender transformative and inclusive demand-creation tools and guidelines, so that health extension workers will implement these in the communities to eliminate open defecation and beyond. Through WASHCOs (community level WASH committees) and school WASH and nutrition clubs, capacity will be built on WASH conditions, MHM and baby WASH. The sub-programme promotes an increase in household investment in WASH (see also pathway 2). The level of participation in decision making of women, girls and socially excluded groups about WASH activities in the community will be increased. The sub-programme creates awareness among women, girls and socially excluded groups of their rights and supportive communities, so that WASH practices and services will be more equitable and sustainable. The gender and WASH monitoring tool will be used to improve and monitor levels of participation of women and socially excluded groups throughout the programme. Through these tools, men and boys will also be targeted to ensure women and girls are given the space within WASH activities and decision making and the (baby) WASH workload is shared more equally.
Pathway 2: By 2022 the programme wants to increase access to water by the construction or rehabilitation of 36 water schemes in the two districts in collaboration with the district government, the private sector and the communities. The sub-programme will improve the WASH market in the districts by strengthening new and existing entrepreneurs in producing and marketing affordable WASH products and by increasing the value of loans given by MFIs and others to producers of WASH products. At least 13.5% of these entrepreneurs will be women. Plan will work closely with the regional WASH bureau, district offices, private sector parties and the communities on the planning, construction and rehabilitation of water schemes and will strengthen them on climate resilience. Plan will establish and strengthen WASH marketing groups of local entrepreneurs to increase the production and provision of WASH products like sanitary pads, soap andclimate resilient latrine options. Female entrepreneurs will be included in the groups and will be motivated and strengthened to run a profitable WASH business. To increase access to credit for WASH businesses, Plan will promote and/or strengthen the WASH entrepreneurs and groups and link them to financial institutions. Plan will train teachers and school pupils (girls and boys) in school WASH clubs on how to make reusable sanitary pads. In order to improve sanitation in schools, Plan and the school management will construct latrines and handwashing facilities for boys and girls. The latrines will include a toilet for people with disabilities and MHM facilities. All facilities will only be constructed after the school management has developed a financial sustainable operation and maintenance plan.
Pathway 3: By 2022, district offices are able to implement service improvement action plans and have improved capacity in monitoring and evaluation of WASH results and expenditures. This will lead to stronger and more coherent WASH sector policies and regulations and increased budget allocation by the district offices for WASH service delivery. The sub-programme calls for gender, inclusion and climate resilience being prioritised in the WASH programmes and sufficient budget allocation to implement these programmes. At a local level, WASHCOs and caretaker committees will have improved capacity in the operation and maintenance of sustainable and inclusive WASH services. Through strengthened WASH governance at district, local and community level in the two districts (Bahir Dar Zuria and Lasta), the government will be able to deliver gender transformative, inclusive and sustainable WASH services in an efficient and effective way. Plan makes use of several entry points, focusing mainly on strengthening the different levels of governance structures. The district health office, the district water office and the district education office will be supported in the development and implementation of their service improvement action plans for which regular meetings between government, service providers and users will be ensured. Through these mechanisms, government may be hold accountable

Pathway 1: Increase demand for improved WASH facilities and practices: Plan aims to make communities aware on improved sanitation and hygienic practices, so that people change their behavior on WASH, and their demand for WASH services will increase. Plan aims to identify and address the root causes of gender inequality in WASH.
Pathway 2: Improve the quality of service provision: Plan aims to make financial institutions aware of the benefits of investing in WASH products and services so that they offer loans for WASH service providers, suppliers, producers (preferably women groups) and households to invest in better access of WASH products and services. In addition, the efficiency and effectiveness of delivery of WASH service providers, suppliers and producers are targeted to be improved so that the supply of WASH products and services improves.
Pathway 3: Improve governance of the sector: Plan will strengthen WASH governance and traditional leadership on gender and socially inclusive and climate resilient WASH, so that WASH gets the attention it needs and sufficient budget is allocated. Existing WASH laws, policies, strategies and regulations will be tested. Women, girls, and socially excluded groups will be actively involved in this process. Plan will also support the government in strengthening their WASH monitoring and evaluation capacity and systems used in order to track WASH progress and WASH expenditures.

Plan International will implement their Ethiopia Bahir Dar Zuria and Lasta sub-programme (SP) in two woredas, situated in two zones, of Amhara national regional state. Bahir Dar Zuria woreda has 36 kebeles, and Lasta has 25 kebeles. The SP will target the two woredas with a total number of 365,800 people.

SUMMARY Because of the poor hygiene and sanitation practice and low service coverage in Ethiopia, the WASH-SDG programme builds on three core strategic objectives: (1) increase demand for improved WASH facilities and practices; (2) improve the quality of service provision; and (3) improve governance of the sector. In addition, gender and social inclusion (GESI), climate vulnerability and resilience (CVR) are integrated transversally in the objectives. In Ethiopia, the WASH-SDG Consortium is represented by WASH Alliance International (WAI – country lead) and Plan. The Plan SP is implemented in rural areas of Bahir Dar Zuria and Lasta (Amhara region). The programme started on the 1st of July 2017 and runs until the 31st of December 2022.

The programme has many different and complementary stakeholders to take into account which all have interests when it comes to WASH. In order to create a sustainable and locally owned programme, all stakeholders have been involved since the inception phase. • Local government has a leading role in defining district WASH priorities and will ensure the programme is governed by government policies, strategies, legislations and procedures. Jointly with Plan, they will facilitate selection of communities and water sources. They will facilitate community planning process and prioritize, appraise and approve community requests and conduct routine programme M&E. Together with the WASHCO’s (WASH Committees), they will provide caretaker (mechanic) training and will provide orientation, information and guidance to kebele stakeholders and leaders on interventions and strategic approaches and tools. • NGOs and CSOs will be responsible for informing, facilitating and mobilizing communities and schools about the interventions to participate and make action plans. They also facilitate the identification and prioritization of target villages and groups. • Private sector will be invited to participate in monitoring and evaluation and will be stimulated to improve WASH service delivery. • Communities will be involved in the planning and will be involved throughout preparation, implementation and monitoring of the interventions.

Route for Youth Economic Empowerment in Guatemala including prevention & response COVID-19

description.narrative: 550 vulnerable youth (60% women) of 30 communities of the municipality San Pedro Carchá will participate in the Entrepreneurship (500 young people) and Employability Clubs (50 young people). The project will also engage 2,200 family members, and 1,000 local clients for the new entrepreneurs.

Guatemala is a young country, with more than 65% of the population under 29 years that faces an unemployment and sub-employment crisis, especially in rural areas with less infrastructure and private sector investment. One-in-four Guatemalan youth neither study nor work, continuously rising rate . In the department of Alta Verapaz, the youth unemployment rate is 5.54% (52% women, 48% men). Although this rate seems low, the economically active population is mainly dedicated to agriculture activities and to work in the informal sector with low incomes and poor working conditions. Among young people in this region, 24% are illiterate and only 44% are studying at the secondary level. Up to 77.2% of these young people live in poverty, with 30.2% in extreme poverty. Furthermore, in the rural areas, for every 10 students, only three are young women. In 2015, 5.713 births were reported among underage girls. As of August 2017, there have been a total of 13 marriages among young women under 18 years of age. Additionally, more than 1,200 cases of violence against women have been reported in the department of Alta Verapaz this year. Many companies do not hire youth, stigmatizing them as violent or assuming they are unmotivated or unqualified, lacking market-responsive skills. This creates a paradox in which youth are unemployed, but also unemployable. Many of the existing jobs remain in urban or peri-urban areas, difficult for rural youth to access. These barriers shortchange both youth and employers, preventing many talented youth from contributing meaningfully to the economy.

Plan will be implementing its Youth Employment Solutions model and pathway to promote entrepreneurship and support youth for their transition to employment based on technical and soft skills trainings. The project is focused on four components to achieve the following outcomes: Component 1: Entrepreneurship pathway: 1. Outcome 1: Youth in entrepreneurship clubs with strengthened entrepreneurial skills and with abilities to generate their own income. Indicators: number of youth participating in clubs; number of youth trained to develop business plans and business management; number of youth equipped with soft skills; organization of Business Start-up event; establishment of new businesses; number of youth who has improved their businesses and participation of youth in commercial fairs. Component 2: Employability pathway 2. Outcome 2: Youth in employment clubs with life skills strengthened and have the ability to pursue wage employment opportunities. Indicators: number of youth participating in clubs; number of youth trained with soft and technical skills; support for job readiness; number of youth placed in jobs and in internship. Component 3: Community awareness 3. Outcome 3: Members of targeted communities support the importance of Youth Economic Empowerment (YEE) and gender equality. Indicators: number of local leaders engaged; number of parents sensitized to support the young people economic empowerment and gender equality; and dialogues initiated to engage influential cultural leaders. Component 4: Enabling environments 4. Strategic alliances with the private sector and governmental institutions strengthened /consolidated. Indicators: agreements signed with institutions and organisations; network of local and regional buyers consolidated.

SUMMARY Guatemala is a young country and 25% of the youth neither study nor work. A rate that continues to rise. This project (April 2019 - October 2021) improves the access of vulnerable youth (60% women) between 18-24 years to market-driven decent work opportunities in communities of San Pedro Carchá (North Guatemala). By strengthening their capacities and improving their businesses and labour skills their incomes will increase and their living conditions will improve. Additionally the project will contribute to the local and regional economies. Plan International implements the project with the Ministry of Economy, Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Agriculture, Tourism Office, municipalities, development councils, National Education Technical Institute (INTECAP) and financial organizations (banks, microfinances). It builds on previous experiences and methodologies such as Entrepreneurship/Employability Clubs, blended approach using mobile technology labs and face-to-face training.

The project builds on the entrepreneurship and employability Clubs, which are key methodologies developed in previous YEE projects and have demonstrated positive results and impact on participating youth. The project supports young entrepreneurs who have started their businesses in previous projects of Plan International. By providing them with technical assistance, mentoring, access to potential clients, these young entrepreneurs will be able to formalize and scale-up their businesses. The Project contributes to the Country Strategy´ Goals 2018-2022 of Plan International Guatemala, and specifically, with the National Program “Learn”. The methodology used is aligned with Plan´s Global of Distinctiveness Area “Skills and Opportunities for Youth Employment and Entrepreneurship” (SOYEE) and the Theory of Change, incorporating key life and work competencies. Furthermore, Plan will strengthen partnerships established in previous projects with the local representatives of the Ministry of Labor, Ministry of Health and Ministry of Agriculture. In this way, Plan will contribute to the socio-economic development of the region supporting these institutions to achieve their own targets.

The project considers the following activities in order to achieve the outcomes and objectives presented in the log frame.
Preparation Phase: • Community awareness raising • Market scan research • Baseline study and gender assessment • Development of detailed working plan and log frame • Startup workshop
Implementation Phase:
Outcome 1: Youth in Entrepreneurship Clubs with strengthened entrepreneurial skills and with abilities to generate their own income. Activities: • Organization of Entrepreneurship Clubs • Soft and Business skills training • Business start-up” event and provision of seed capital • Business development and start-up • Business skills training • Participation in commercial fairs
Outcome 2: Youth in Employment Clubs with life skills strengthened and have the ability to pursue wage employment opportunities. Activities: • Private sector engagement • Organization of Employment Clubs • Training on life skills and job readiness • Technical training • Job placement and Internships.
Outcome 3. Members of targeted communities support the importance of Youth Economic Empowerment (YEE) and gender equality. Activities: • Awareness activities for local leaders and community • Sensitized workshops with parents • Dialogues to engage influential cultural leaders
Outcome 4. Strategic alliances with the private sector and governmental institutions strengthened /consolidated. Activities:
• Partner institutions provide technical assistance in business management and/or training to young entrepreneurs using the Michael Porters Value Chain model • Develop Network of local and regional suppliers and buyers

Young people will be generating their own income and investing in improving their quality of life. Capacities and skills are built to continue managing their businesses so that their productive units are stable and sustainable in the local and regional markets. This will allow them positioning their products in the top of the minds of their customers. Also Plan will provide technical assistance and accompaniment for six months after businesses have started by young entrepreneurs to guarantee sustainability. Network of suppliers and buyers will be established to facilitate cooperation within the value chain and identify new market opportunities.
A network of governmental counterparts will be strengthen at the local level that will be bringing technical assistance, training, internship, jobs, access to market and access to financial services to grow up the new entrepreneurs businesses and sustain employment to the participating young people. Plan raises awareness in these institutions on the importance on gender equality and youth economic empowerment.
The project increases the infrastructure of the mobile technology “Nómada” that will be used for future youth economic empowerment projects of Plan in other regions in Guatemala. The “Nómada” infrastructure provides a portable television, 16 tablets, benches, and a computer for the Clubs.
The community will be sensitized on gender equality and young women will be economically empowered within an environment that promotes productive investment in youth and especially in young women. The private sector will be sensitized of youth empowerment and in gender equality in workplace.

FOA COVID-19 Response Fund

description.narrative:
SUMMARY
This fund is a contribution to the Plan International global appeal for COVID-19 which aims at providing critical support to people affected by Covid-19 through activities centred around the prevention, mitigation and response to Covid-19 and the negative effects thereof.

policy-marker.narrative: Protection and Assistance in Emergencies (Disaster Risk Management)

title.narrative: Let Girls Be Born phase III incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: A multi- sectoral strategy which is governed by the core principles of respecting, protecting and fulfilling the rights of girls and women, including addressing gender based violence will be adopted. To create improved awareness on value for girl child, gender biased discrimination & GBV in their respective communities, communities and key persons as agents of change will be identified and trained. This will be done by the following strategies: 1) Evolving a sustained social mobilization and communication campaign to change societal norms in favour of creating equal value for the girl child. 2) Mobilizing and empowering frontline workers’ teams as catalysts for social change, in partnership with local community/women’s/youth groups 3) Developing capacity of Urban local bodies - especially women urban local body members- to create community and peer support for making urban wards girl child friendly. 4) Ensure that service delivery structures are sufficiently responsive to issues of gender and children’s rights. 5) Enabling Inter-departments and inter-institutional convergence at different levels. The last two strategies will make sure that states are engaged and state level actions implemented.

LGBB, which started as a flagship project of Plan India is evolving into a program and is being integrated into Plan India’s sponsorship areas towards a more comprehensive approach, at the same time to see how the combined process of communication and community motivation can together aim for reaching the objectives of the project. Coordinated and convergent efforts are needed to ensure survival, protection and education of girl child to help realize her full potential and this is being recognized by the Government of India. In response to the need for urgent action, Government announced, Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao (Empower Girls & encourage Education) (BBBP) to empower the girl child and enable her education in July, 2014 The targeted states of LGBB Phase III are also aligned with the newly launched national campaign BBBP National Scheme and is implemented currently in the same districts of the EU project & blocks. The strategy will be complementing each other to have a holistic approach. Recognizing that the issue of decline in child sex ratio is complex and multi-dimensional, it shall be addressed within the broad framework of survival and protection of girl children.

Prenatal Sex selection in India causes the loss of 500,000 girls every year. It varies between states, with most dramatic decline in Punjab ( 793 girls / 1000 boys). The major factors that underlie son preference are the economic utility of sons being more likely than daughters to provide family labor and support their parents during old age, secondly the social status of having more sons, thus more power. Finally, having sons arises from the important religious functions that only sons can provide. Next to this a daughter is considered to be an economic liability to her parents mainly because of the heavy dowry payment as well as the high cost of the wedding. The introduction of new reproductive technologies including amniocentesis and ultrasonography has aggravated the problem by providing sex selection services at very cheap prices (Rs 400). These modern technologies which were invented for identification of genetic or other abnormalities in the foetus are grossly misused by detecting the sex of the unborn child for the sake of son preference. Over the next 20 years, in parts of India there will be a 12-15% excess of young men leading to a situation of bride shortage for prospective grooms. This can give rise to substantial increase in aggressions and organized crimes, rape and other forms of violence against women, drug and alcohol abuse, situation where many men in a family share single wife and inter community trafficking of girls.

Result 1: Community & identified stakeholders ( adolescents, newly-wed couples and families) demonstrating improved awareness on value for girl child, gender biased discrimination & GBV in their respective communities. • Community will be mobilized to ensure participation of men, women, youths in different participatory forums and activities. • 20% of Youths, young couples, adolescents will be reached • 7200 young leaders (2520 male & 2520 females) will be trained as youth leaders to act as community motivators • Strengthening existing community platforms Result 2: Communication Strategy replicated or adapted for implementation at scale by government. • State and district level advocacy meetings • Linkage with National health Mission & State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (SCPCR) • Establish state consultative groups for effective implementation of government schemes and provisions for the girl child and for implementation of PCPNDT Act. • Facilitating civil society networks • Orientation of the identified (media, judicial & health etc.) critical stakeholders • Block Level Child Protection Committees (BLCPC) will be either strengthened or formed Result 3: Government officials & service providers demonstrating awareness & improved service delivery for improving value of the girl child. • Capacity building on gender, family life education, legislations for front line workers and health workers • Supporting the community workers in developing counselling skills • Birth registration: coordination will be facilitated with Birth & Registration departments /Health department for organising camps for issuance of the birth certificates

SUMMARY India has the worst child sex ratio in the world (927 girls/1000 boys). Since 2010, the LGBB project has been able to influence policy makers through different actions. The project uses a campaign mode combined with community actions which were demonstrated as best practices. As a result Plan International India has been recognized by the government as a technical support agency on the issue of declining child sex ratio in the implementation of LGBB phase I and II. The project will work with an approach that combines communication and community motivation to reach the objectives. It is carried out in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Jharkhand & Delhi. Delhi will also be included for the purpose of advocacy. The project will address community, adolescents, newly married couples and the government.

The project will work with young people constituting one-fifth of the total population in the proposed intervention areas, government officials, PRIs, frontline functionaries (Asha/AWW, ANM) and other stakeholders like judiciary, media etc

First Steps' Big Step: Early Childhood development and positive parenting in Jordan

description.narrative: 13% of children aged 36-59 months are attending ECD programs, compared to 22% in 2012 in Jordan. There are significant shortcomings in access, participation and quality of current ECD provision according to a recent HRD report. To address these gaps and build on lessons learned, Plan International is implementing a follow-on project that builds on the first 2-year project by scaling-up parenting services to 15 health centres, continued engagement in national policy change through the ECD Team. This project empowers parents through community-based approaches to learning to create a more nurturing home environment to better respond to children’s needs without gender discrimination or violence. It will use a revised parenting curriculum with lessons learned from past programming pulling on ECD theory, psychosocial support for parents and violence prevention, as well as gender transformative learning. While in parallel enacting structures within the national architecture to sustain policy level changes to integrate ECD as a comprehensive approach to the care for young children. Through strategic alliances with the Jordanian Ministry of Health and Education, national CBOs and NGOs as well as UNICEF Jordan.

Caregivers of young children from vulnerable backgrounds e.g. refugees, asylum seekers, families living in poverty or affected by other discrimination prohibiting integration into the community. ECD services for children under 6 years old will be provided. Finally adult professionals at the Ministry of Health, Education and MOH centres.

Early childhood development creates a lasting impact on a child’s future outcomes as it lays the foundation for future wellbeing and resilience. Children living in poverty, social exclusion or affected by conflict often lack access to a safe, nurturing and supportive environment in which to grow. Evidence shows that parents living under such hardship have a particularly difficult time spending the mental energy required to provide ECD for their children. With the onset of the Syrian crisis in 2011, Jordan’s national social welfare systems and resources became severely strained and unable to meet the demand of new arrivals. Children account for 66% of the population and are impacted by poverty more than other age group. UNICEF observed that evidence required to monitor the development of children in Jordan needs improvement with inadequate data to inform policy and implementation of social services for children. Therefore we will support the National ECD Team to focus on this gap. Parenting programmes will be installed within health centres to reach more parents on the importance of ECD and positive parenting.

In year one the project will focus on capacity building for the local partners, especially the ROYAL HEALTH AWARENESS SOCIETY (RHAS) who will take over responsibility for implementing the parenting package inside the MOH health centres nation wide. As such the first 6 months is an inception phase focussed on planning, training, mapping and preparing the teams to deliver quality programming to the most in need communities. Further, we will be adapting our parenting curriculum to reflect the most up-to-date guidance from global leaders in ECD and to reflect best practices from the first project. This will be done in consultation with partners, stakeholders and UNICEF.
During this time, our behavioural science research partner will conduct background research and scoping of the problems related to poor positive parenting update among marginalised groups in Jordan. Additionally, the National ECD Team will resume activities and begin to make strides in order to prioritise ECD at the national level across all sectors. Due to the focus on COVID-19 response and resources demanded led by the MOH our main stakeholder, there has been a negative shift in focus from the previous project cycle away from ECD to prioritise the public health emergency. Therefore it is essential to maintain visibility among ministerial partners of the long term importance to focus on ECD for young children.
From January, we will begin service delivery either via an online platform, or in person workshops with parents and caregivers depending on the current covid-19 movement restrictions and ensuring the safety of the community is at the forefront. Our curriculum will be digitalise to ensure easy adaptation based on the operational context ensure the safety of the most vulnerable is always prioritised. This will be closely followed by behavioural science specialists to support, track and monitor the uptake and impact n order to learn and adapt the approach as needed.

Our primary investment objective is to effectively support parents and caregivers to be more responsive and empowered to nurture children in an safe, enabling environment where ECD services are integrated across service providers and sectors to become a national priority. To create access to quality ECD services and for ECD to be prioritised, demand needs to be generated bottom up from parents/ caregivers as well as supported top down. By advancing postive parenting across multiple government bodies this project ensures that children are more effectively nurtured and parents are enabled to better support children’s developmental milestones and protect child’s rights. We will roll out the parenting model by year three in 15 health centres across Jordan. These centres have been selected in collaboration with government and partner organisations based on a mapping of all 600 health centres, and a criteria for population diversity, and number of persons in the health centre catchment. We will conduct behavioural science research to investiagte the most effective and impactful approaches to integrate into our parenting currculum and mode of delivery and outreach.

Plan focuses on building human and social capital as it is integral to strategic community investment; it leverages and multiplies the impact of the intervention by strengthening local partner organizations, increasing the likelihood of project success and sustainability. Plan has focused part of its intervention in government-run health centres instead of stand alone sites to increase the likelihood that the MOH can integrate this approach into their core functionality in the long term. Working hand in hand with MOH staff and through local partners already well integrated into the national systems, Plan International will provide capacity building and training opportunities for health and education staff ECD, psychosocial support, refugee and migrant rights, child protection identification and referral. This seeks to strengthen the uptake of ECD for vulnerable populations from the grassroots tot he ministerial level and thereby creating space and prioritisation at national level.

SUMMARY First Steps’ Big Step is a three-year programme funded for the first year by the Bernard van Leer Foundation and Plan International Netherlands. Its goal is for children under five years, born into vulnerable and marginalised households, receive the care, nurture and support services they need for healthy growth development to reach their full potential, free from harmful gendered norms and attitudes that are discriminatory and limiting. In order to achieve the this, the programme adopts two pathways that ensure parents and caregivers practice gender transformative and age appropriate non-violent parenting behaviours, and that Early Children Development becomes an integrated and comprehensive national priority in Jordan. It will be implemented across 15 Mother and Child Centres targeting 2,225 parents and 100 frontline staff implemented by Plan International and local partners. It is supported by a behavioural science research to capture best practices.

WASH First: Scaling up WASH SDG efforts: the first line of defence against COVID-19 - Kenya

description.narrative: At the start of the health crisis, the government was acting quickly and CSO's had no role in the decision taking process. However, space for civil society to engage with government remained as government was actively seeking involvement. This program has been developed in coordination with the Ministry of Health. Local actors like community workers, WASH committees, sanitation workers, schools, WASH service providers and government officials will be trained on how to reduce transmission of COVID-19 virus. Plan Kenya has a presence in the intervention areas and has a working relationship with government and other stakeholders. Plan implements directly and through its local partner the Real Hope Youth and Community Organization (RHYCO), and has experience with the implementation of WASH programs. The program is fully aligned with the Emergency Response Program that had been prepared in the context of the pandemic.

Institutional: By involving local government and local stakeholders, the ownership of the program will be anchored in the local institutional structure.
Social: The active participation of the target groups is essential to ensure that we respond to their specific needs. The overall goal of this program is the “promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 through awareness raising and improved access to WASH services.” The intervention will ensure that the achievement of the SDG 6 goals does not come to a standstill in the intervention areas.

Plan International Kenya will implement the following activities on the 6 intervention strategies:
Intervention strategy 1: Awareness raising (campaigns and mass media campaigns) on COVID-19 • Raise awareness in communities on COVID-19 prevention, using different methodologies such as the use of murals that have been strategically painted on walls and billboards • Use media and participate in the talk shows
Intervention strategy 2: Direct information sharing and messaging • Support the sensitisation of CHV/Ws in charge of COVID-19 prevention messaging and control management. • Strengthen the capacity of girl’s advocates for peer support on COVID-19 prevention and information sharing and advocacy on issues concerning children and girls. • Raise awareness in schools using the COVID-19 prevention guidelines for schools that are currently being developed. • Promote social distancing measures around WASH facilities and prioritise access for elderly/disabled/ pregnant people. • Work with CHW/Vs so they can distribute contextualised prevention messages.
Intervention strategy 3: Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste) • Support communities to access water for handwashing and consumption. Handwashing units will be placed in strategic places. • Truck water to strategic water storage facilities for ease of access. • Support adolescent girls living in urban informal settlements in having access to bathrooms by paying the public toilet use fee. • Ensure vulnerable people have access to WASH facilities. • Install handwash units in schools and make MHM products available for girls.
Intervention strategy 4: Improving access to safe handwashing facilities • Place handwashing units in strategic places with liquid soap that are also accessible for the disabled and elderly. • Provide handwashing units and liquid soap in schools when they reopen in January 2021.
Intervention strategy 5: Access to hygiene products including soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products • Provide appropriate hygiene kits and sanitary towels for girls and support them in accessing bathrooms for personal hygiene in urban informal settlements. • Ensure vulnerable people have access to hygiene products. • Collaborate with the MoH to procure infection prevention materials such as disinfectants, and detergents in order to ensure there is adequate disinfection at critical areas including schools, public transport facilities and health facilities. MoH guidelines on IPC will be followed. • Disinfect schools before the planned re-opening, as some have been used as isolation centres. • Where necessary, procure and supply sanitisers to health care workers and teachers. • Procure and distribute masks, both surgical and reusable, for health care workers and CHVs. Masks will also be given to vulnerable people within the selected communities.
Intervention strategy 6: COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders • Collaborate with the MoH and other partners to update information on the pandemic as appropriate. • Support national measures and initiatives to share more information on COVID-19 transmission prevention and control. • Support the development of appropriate gender sensitive and inclusive messages for communities, taking into consideration their literacy level and ability to understand.

SUMMARY The WASH First program in Kenya started in 2020 and is part of the scaling-up efforts of the WASH SDG Consortium and its main objective is to prevent further spread of COVID19. Plan International Kenya started the implementation of the program in the urban informal settlements of Kibera and Kawangware of Nairobi and in Kilifi North (town), Rabai and Kaloleni. These areas have been hit hard by the pandemic. The program will organize awareness raising campaigns on COVID-19. It further will promote direct messaging and information sharing. And finally, it will improve access to water, sanitation, handwashing facilities and (menstrual) hygiene products.

The end beneficiaries of the programme activities will be the vulnerable and at risk groups living in the low income informal urban settlements Kibera and Kawangware of Nairobi and in Kilifi Noth and the rural areas of Rabai and Kaloleni.

The first cases of Covid-19 were detected early 2020 and government took the measures like promoting social distancing, handwashing and wearing face masks. Quarantine centers were setup for people diagnosed with the disease and large gatherings were forbidden. A lockdown and curfew were in effect during the first months. The project intervention areas were selected in coordination with Ministry of Health (MoH) and had already limited access to WASH facilities. Many of the residents of the informal urban settlements Kibera and Kawangware of Nairiobi had already pre-existing medical conditions like tuberculosis and HIV. More underaged girls were forced to marriage and more teenage girls got pregnant. Lockdown and curfew also increased the risk of violence for women and girls when visiting public toilets at night. In the rural areas people have almost no access to water and sanitation. Because schools were closed children had less access to WASH facilities. Lockdown also caused more cases of Gender Based Violence. People with disabilities face challenges in accessing WASH services and prevention messaging. The fear of stigmatisation of being diagnosed with Covid-19 complicated the track and trace efforts of the MoH.

The main objective of the program is: Promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 in at-risk countries through awareness raising and improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene services Result areas: 1. Enhanced understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission 2. Population at risk of Covid-19 have sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables (i.e. handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products) and personal protective equipment (PPEs) 3. Population at risk of COVID-19 have safe (considering safeguarding and security) access to Water and Sanitation services through the construction of new and repair of non-functional water facilities or through temporary/mobile services/supplies. Support adolescent girls living in urban informal settlements in having access to bathrooms by paying the public toilet use fee

title.narrative: Yes I do Mozambique incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys make families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves and claim their rights are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRHR information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

EM and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM) and teenage pregnancies. With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’ Embassy to Mozambique, similar projects under the same framework will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Zambia, Indonesia and Pakistan.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH rights. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies.

title.narrative: 0154 Children, youth or adults have skills to make changes to their lives
% boys aged 15-24 who disagree with the statement It is not appropriate for a girl to propose to use a condom

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in the intervention area (Mogovolas). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1430 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1482 questionnaires were administered- very slightly above the planned target.

comment.narrative: % boys aged 15-24 who disagree with the statement It is not appropriate for a girl to propose to use a condom

No end line data available for this quantitative indicator. Due to COVID-19 and the related school closure in September 2020, it was not possible to use the same sampling framework for the end-line survey as for 2016 baseline study in Mogovolas (household sample n=715) and the 2017 Nampula and Rapale study (school-based sample n=943). The end-line survey therefore targeted young people (15-24 years, both female and male) involved in the Champions of Change activities in all three districts: Mogovolas (n=55), Nampula (n=35) and Rapale (n=74). The different sampling frame used for the end-line as result of COVID-19, makes comparison with the previous studies not possible and therefore, only the qualitative indicators have received a value in the IATI reporting. The qualitative component of the endline consists of interviews and focus group discussions with 41 young women and 21 young men (15-24 years).

We obtained a sample size of 1430 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1482 questionnaires were administered- very slightly above the planned target.

comment.narrative: % of girls below 18 years old who are currently married

title.narrative: % of girls below 18 years who left school due to marriage

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in the intervention area (Mogovolas). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1430 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1482 questionnaires were administered- very slightly above the planned target.

comment.narrative: % of girls below 18 years who left school due to marriage

No end line data available for this quantitative indicator. Due to COVID-19 and the related school closure in September 2020, it was not possible to use the same sampling framework for the end-line survey as for 2016 baseline study in Mogovolas (household sample n=715) and the 2017 Nampula and Rapale study (school-based sample n=943). The end-line survey therefore targeted young people (15-24 years, both female and male) involved in the Champions of Change activities in all three districts: Mogovolas (n=55), Nampula (n=35) and Rapale (n=74). The different sampling frame used for the end-line as result of COVID-19, makes comparison with the previous studies not possible and therefore, only the qualitative indicators have received a value in the IATI reporting. The qualitative component of the endline consists of interviews and focus group discussions with 41 young women and 21 young men (15-24 years).

title.narrative: 0551 Service providers are capable to deliver services that are sensitive to rights of children and youth and gender equality (C2)
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

"Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all General security inside and outside school is not seen as a problem in Nametil. However, stigma and discrimination of teenage mothers is an issue, and reference was made to some cases of sexual abuse by teachers.

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults decide about their own future
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 – 24 years old

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 – 24 years old

"Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The large majority of stakeholders in Nametil said that young people, both girls and boys, decide for themselves these days whether they get married and or start having a relationship. A number of young unmarried women interviewed confirmed this, and said they are able to decided for themselves with whom to date and marry. Other young women said that it are parents who determine when and who to marry and that such a decision depends on the economic situation and or pregnancies. The majority of the stakeholders and most adults said that forced marriages are not common. Young people feel they have very little income and employment opportunities.

title.narrative: 0652 Policy makers know the rights of children and youth and are willing to act accordingly
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively/openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively/openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

"Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Policy officers in local administrations in Nametil do not make explicit references to the concept of gender equality with the exception of few. However they talk openly about initiatives focusing on the protection and support of young women, especially in educational level.

0212 Communities take charge of their own development processes
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)
Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all

Various gatekeepers in Nametil are undertaking actions to prevent child marriage and teenage pregnancy. These actions are mainly led by health providers and some teachers and are focused on providing information, oftentimes through palestras, and access to contraceptives. In addition, some teachers/schools encourage girls to continu to go to school to prevent child marriage and teenage pregnancy. A few stakeholders mentioned to have proactively visited parents to try to avoid a specific case of child marriage.

title.narrative: 0411 The private sector responds to the needs and rights of children and youth
Number of private sector businesses that have taken initiatives in support of children and youth
Menstrual Hygiene Management incl COVID prevention

description.narrative: Existing projects are strengthened and more coherence and synergy within the programme portfolio of Plan will be created. Income generating aspect of this project, when skills are learnt to produce cheap local pads, will create sustainability and enable the trained groups to continue. Teachers are sensitized to include MHM information in their schools and are trained to provide safe spaces for girls and will lobby for appropriate sanitation ate schools. This MHM initiative will promote the use of existing budget lines in schools for MHM.

Many children in Mozambique do not complete education. Between 2007 and 2016, students who complete seven years of schooling annually represent only 45.6% on average. And only 30% of the students who enter first grade annually complete the 70th grade in seven years. There is also a persistent gender gap. Compared to boys less girls complete primary and secondary education and girls have higher drop-out rates particularly at the secondary level. One of the reasons why girls in Mozambique cannot fully realise their right to education is linked to menstruation. Often, facilities for girls (sanitary towels, separate WCs / latrines, water) are not available at school, and girls may rather prefer to stay at home. As a result many girls fall behind their peers and even drop-out from education completely. The problem is poorly recognized.
Research about the relation between menstruation and school attendance specifically for Mozambique is not available, but the WHO estimates that 1 in 10 school-age African girls ‘do not attend school during menstruation’ (Progress on sanitation and drinking-water – 2013 update. Geneva, WHO.) Similarly , statistics from the WB shows that girls are absent from school 4 days every 4 weeks on average.

SUMMARY The project will introduce Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM) in existing projects on Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) that directly work with schools and youth. By developing good MHM practices at schools it is expected that female drop-out rates will decrease and the capacity of girls to claim their right to education and participate in social, political and economic life will increase. One of the main activities is to develop and promote modules for MHM activities for use in these projects that target adolescents through primary and secondary schools, but also through youth clubs, Village Savings and Loan (VSL) groups or other relevant social structures. The project started on 1 July 2019 as a pilot and is a component of the Wutomi SRHR project in Inhambane, Mozambique. After one year, scaling up is foreseen in other SRHR programmes in Mozambique. The project is implemented by Plan Mozambique.

The MHM project will focus on the following activities: 1. Advise and train project staff (PIM and partners) about MHM inclusion 2. Develop tailor-made interventions for MHM. May include minor rehabilitation of WASH facilities 3. (Co-)implement tailor-made interventions for MHM (per project) 4. Facilitating awareness raising activities in schools and communities 5. Liaise with schools and enrich school curriculum with MHM issues, including education for girls and boys on how to produce low-cost hygienic sanitary pads from locally available materials 6. Liaise with VSLA groups and introduce the production of low-cost hygienic sanitary pads from locally available materials for auto-consumption or as IGA.
In the first year the MHM project will link up with the Wutomi project in Inhambane, which is working in 8 schools already and planning to work with 7 VSLAs in 2019. This project provides a good breeding ground for the development of good MHM modules. Thereafter, experiences gained in Wutomi will be scaled up to other projects in Inhambane (18+) and Nampula (Yes I Do and Health Women and Girls).
The module will be adapted to the intervention context at hand in close collaboration with the soliciting development agency (Plan or Plan-partners). The contextualised MHM intervention will be accompanied with staff training and be monitored and implemented jointly with the development agent’s staff. There will be synergetic effects with government policies. The “Plano Estratégico da Educação 2012-2016” (not renewed yet), aims to tackle gender disparities in education. Already, school budgets allow for spending on MHM, which hardly ever occurs. This MHM initiative will promote the use of existing budget lines in schools for MHM.

The proposed MHM intervention does not only addresses the practical needs of girls, but also addresses the underlying social norms about sexuality, reproductive health and gender norms. Providing opportunities for girls for menstrual hygiene like proper sanitation, safe spaces and education about MHM, will increase their school participation as they will have an enabling environment at school for this.

title.narrative: WASH First: Scaling up WASH SDG efforts: the first line of defence against COVID-19- Mozambique

description.narrative:
Institutional: The program interventions will be implemented in close coordination with the government and formal and informal community leaders. The program will also coordinate with government for consistency in messaging on COVID-1 prevention
Social: The active participation of the target groups is essential to ensure that we respond to their specific needs. The overall goal of this program is the “promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 through awareness raising and improved access to WASH services.” The intervention will ensure that the achievement of the SDG 6 goals does not come to a standstill in the intervention areas. The program is inclusive and will adapt hygiene messages to promote positive gender relations and avoid exacerbating negative gender stereotypes. It will further promote do no harm promotion principles and support existing child protection referral mechanism. The rights of children will be promoted and protected, especially girls' rights, strengthening the existing referral mechanisms (existing toll free hotlines), making use of community radio to raise awareness and promote no harm practices wherever possible, using same platforms for HBC campaigns.

On March 22 2020 the Ministry of Health declared there was an outbreak of COVID-19 in the country. The virus was spreading quickly and Nampula province was severely affected. Located in the North, it is the most populated province and among the poorest with the lowest district-level WASH facilities. Cholera outbreaks and diarrhea are often reported. Hygiene practices are poor and only 10% of the population has access to handwashing facilities. Schools were closed, affecting almost eight million students across the country. Since July schools started reopening but the lack of sufficient WASH facilities was an obstacle to a safe opening of the schools. The COVID-19 crisis has exacerbated the pre-existing inequalities and poverty, affecting especially the most vulnerable and marginalised people. While it is acknowledged that good hygiene can slow the spread of the virus, the communities in the intervention area have poor access to WASH. This puts families at higher risk of infection and increases vulnerability of girls and women when they go to collect water. Women and girl do not have access to public health messages because they are not linked to information networks and their levels of literacy are low.

Plan International Mozambique will implement the following activities on the 6 intervention strategies:
Intervention strategy 1: Awareness raising (campaigns and mass media campaigns) on COVID-19 • Based on the rapid assessment, a hygiene behaviour communication plan will be developed. Careful attention will be given when developing the messages to ensure they will trigger the emotions of people and not just raise awareness. The messages developed will focus on positive emotions, highlighting the health benefits if handwashing is done correctly and frequently and the benefits of protecting others and not spreading the coronavirus. • Develop communication materials, including radio and TV spots. Mixed methods for mass messaging will be used, including community radio, visual materials and TV spots, ensuring the communication campaigns will expose vulnerable people at least three times to the messages, to increase their capability and motivation to acquire good habits. The communications materials will contain illustrative graphics focused on the geographical context (Nampula province settings – houses, clothes, daily activities) but discouraging stereotypes ( such as gender stereotypes). • Training sessions will be delivered to key hygiene promoters (government staff, community health workers, community radio producers, teachers, community leaders) on the communication plan and campaign approaches. The training will be conducted outdoors, respecting the government regulations and Ministry of Health advices on social distancing and the number of participants. • The campaign will use stories, songs and demonstrations. It will be phased, focusing first on mass communications to comply with the movement restrictions and social distancing.
Intervention strategy 2: Direct information sharing and messaging through home visits, courtyard meetings and community meetings, where possible and in line with do no harm principles • Rolling out gender sensitive and inclusive communication campaign through outdoors sessions (when schools re-open) and community sensitisation • Priority will be given to aligning the messages with the Ministry of Health to avoid confused communications and disinformation. Adapt hygiene messages to promote positive gender relations and avoid exacerbating negative gender stereotypes. • Do no harm promotion and support of existing child protection referral mechanism. We will promote and protect the rights of children, especially girls, strengthening the existing referral mechanisms (existing toll free hotlines), making use of community radio to raise awareness and promote no harm practices wherever possible, using same platforms for HBC campaigns
Intervention strategy 3: Improving access to safe drinking water and water supply for handwashing, as well as menstrual health and sanitation (including safe disposal of waste) • Geophysical studies will be carried out to assess suitable locations for drilling water boreholes. • Provision of water access in three communities. • For each borehole, a water committee will be formed and community members (half women and half men) trained to maintain the water point and collect fees. This activity will be conducted in collaboration with public works technicians. A training package on gender based violence and child protection will be also provided. • Ensure that access is organised in a gender friendly and social inclusive way while taking in consideration social distancing.
Intervention strategy 4: Improving access to safe handwashing facilities • Plan will promote no-cost or low cost handwashing stations such as tippy taps that families can set up easily in their home. Tippy taps will allow family members to wash their hands with soap and poured water for the right amount of time and using the correct technique.
Intervention strategy 5: Access to hygiene products such as soap, disinfectant, PPE and menstrual hygiene products • Purchasing and distribution of hygiene kits and dignity/MHM kits reaching the most vulnerable. Immediate intervention is needed for distribution of soap and hygiene kits for the poorest families. These will be identified in coordination with the authorities, community leaders and local partners. Poor adolescents girls and young women will receive dignity kits, including menstrual hygiene management products, to boost their confidence and ensure dignity.
Intervention strategy 6: COVID-related coordination meetings with local government and other stakeholders • The sub-programme interventions will be implemented in close coordination with the government and formal and informal community leaders. • The sub-programme will also coordinate with government for consistency in messaging on COVID-19 prevention.

Plan Mozambique, through the Nampula Programme Unit, has a proven track record of supporting programmes across 24 communities in Mogovolas district. Plan has a strong experience in implementing WASH-related interventions. A WASH consultant provides technical support on the implementation of Plan WASH projects. In addition, Plan will leverage on previous project experiences being implemented in Nampula in areas of hygiene, MHM and SRHR. The Nampula Programme Unit is carrying out COVID-19 prevention and hygiene awareness and community sensitisation on SRHR, as per its country COVID-19 response plan.

SUMMARY The WASH First programme in Mozambique started in 2020 and is part of the scaling-up efforts of the WASH SDG Consortium. Its main objective is to prevent further spread of COVID-19. Plan International Mozambique started the implementation of the programme in Mogovolas district, Nampula province. This area has been hit hard by the pandemic. The programme will organise awareness raising campaigns on COVID-19. It will also promote direct messaging and information sharing. Through the programme we will improve access to water, sanitation, handwashing facilities and (menstrual) hygiene products.

The end beneficiaries will be the most poor and vulnerable people living in Mogovolas district, Nampula province that boarders Cabo Delgado province where violent incidents have been recorded causing a refugee flow into Nampula province.

The main objective of the program is: Promotion of health-related hygiene practices to prevent further spread of COVID-19 in at-risk countries through awareness raising and improved access to WASH services
Result areas: 1. Enhanced understanding of individuals, communities, health workers, schools and WASH service providers about mitigation measures against COVID-19 transmission 2. Population at risk of Covid-19 have sufficient and constant access to commodities and consumables (i.e. handwashing facilities, disinfection equipment, soap, hygiene kits including menstrual health products) and personal protective equipment (PPEs) 3. Population at risk of COVID-19 have safe (considering safeguarding and security) access to Water and Sanitation services through the construction of new and repair of non-functional water facilities or through temporary/mobile services/supplies.

title.narrative: Yes I do Malawi incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves and claim their rights are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRHR information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

During the inception phase (January – June 2016) country-specific plans will be developed, target groups and final beneficiaries identified and activities that are based on the overall intervention strategies will be designed.

EM and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM) and teenage pregnancies. With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’ Embassy (located in in Harare, Zimbabwe). Next to Malawi, similar projects under the same framework will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH rights. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies.
This will be worked out per country.
